raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good user advocate.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A user-centric design philosophy that prioritizes the needs and experience of the end-user.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good security professional.

raw.text: Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it.

raw.note: The most famous aphorism on the importance of studying history to avoid repeating past mistakes.

raw.text: The farther backward you can look, the farther forward you are likely to see.

raw.text: History, despite its wrenching pain, cannot be unlived, but if faced with courage, need not be lived again.

raw.text: The past is never dead. It's not even past.

raw.text: History is who we are and why we are the way we are.

raw.text: History is not a burden on the memory but an illumination of the soul.

raw.text: The most effective way to destroy people is to deny and obliterate their own understanding of their history.

raw.text: A generation which ignores history has no past and no future.

raw.text: History is the version of past events that people have decided to agree upon.

raw.text: The history of all hitherto existing society is the history of class struggles.

raw.text: To be ignorant of what occurred before you were born is to remain always a child.
raw.author: Cicero
raw.note: An ancient Roman statesman's view on the necessity of historical knowledge for intellectual maturity.

raw.text: History is a gallery of pictures in which there are few originals and many copies.

raw.text: The past does not repeat itself, but it rhymes.

raw.text: History is a race between education and catastrophe.
raw.author: H.G. Wells
raw.note: A statement on the critical role of learning and wisdom in preventing societal collapse.

raw.text: The very ink with which history is written is merely fluid prejudice.
raw.author: Mark Twain
raw.note: A cynical take on the inherent bias in all historical writing.

raw.text: Memory is the diary that we all carry about with us.

raw.text: The difference between history and memory is that history is the story of the past, and memory is the story of the past in the present.

raw.text: History is written by the victors.
raw.author: Winston Churchill
raw.note: A famous aphorism acknowledging that the dominant historical narrative is usually shaped by those who win conflicts.

raw.text: The safest general characterization of the European philosophical tradition is that it consists of a series of footnotes to Plato.

raw.text: If you want to understand today, you have to search yesterday.

raw.text: History is a guide to navigation in perilous times. History is who we are and why we are the way we are.

raw.text: We are not enemies, but friends. We must not be enemies. Though passion may have strained, it must not break our bonds of affection. The mystic chords of memory will yet swell the chorus of the Union, when again touched, as surely they will be, by the better angels of our nature.

raw.text: I learned that courage was not the absence of fear, but the triumph over it. The brave man is not he who does not feel afraid, but he who conquers that fear.

raw.text: The ultimate measure of a man is not where he stands in moments of comfort and convenience, but where he stands at times of challenge and controversy.

raw.text: I would rather be a rebel than a slave.

raw.text: I am only one, but I am one. I cannot do everything, but I can do something. And I will not let what I cannot do interfere with what I can do.

raw.text: I have a dream that one day this nation will rise up and live out the true meaning of its creed: 'We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal.'

raw.text: A hero is someone who has given his or her life to something bigger than oneself.

raw.note: A definition of heroism based on sacrifice for a greater cause.

raw.text: I am not afraid of an army of lions led by a sheep; I am afraid of an army of sheep led by a lion.

raw.note: An ancient observation on the supreme importance of strong leadership.

raw.text: If you tremble with indignation at every injustice, then you are a comrade of mine.

raw.text: The true hero is one who conquers his own anger and hatred.

raw.text: A hero is an ordinary individual who finds the strength to persevere and endure in spite of overwhelming obstacles.

raw.note: A definition of heroism based on resilience and perseverance in the face of adversity.

raw.text: I think a hero is any person really intent on making this a better place for all people.

raw.note: A broad and inclusive definition of heroism based on positive intention and action.

raw.text: The legacy of heroes is the memory of a great name and the inheritance of a great example.

raw.note: A statement on the two primary components of a hero's legacy: reputation and moral example.

raw.text: The hero is one who kindles a great light in the world, who sets up blazing torches in the dark streets of life for men to see by.
raw.author: Felix Adler
raw.note: A metaphor for the hero as a source of inspiration, guidance, and hope.

raw.text: A hero is born among a hundred, a wise man is found among a thousand, but an accomplished one might not be found even among a hundred thousand men.

raw.note: A philosophical observation on the rarity of true heroism and wisdom.

raw.text: True heroism is remarkably sober, very undramatic. It is not the urge to surpass all others at whatever cost, but the urge to serve others at whatever cost.

raw.note: A definition of heroism based on selfless service rather than competitive glory.

raw.text: The hero is the man who is afraid to run away.

raw.text: The hero is never the one who is right, but the one who is not afraid to be wrong.

raw.text: The hero is the one who, in the end, is not a hero but a human being.

raw.text: Never mistake knowledge for wisdom. One helps you make a living; the other helps you make a life.
raw.author: Sandra Carey
raw.note: A distinction between the practical application of knowledge and the deeper understanding of how to live well.

raw.text: The older I get, the more I listen.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple observation that wisdom often correlates with a greater capacity for listening.

raw.text: Wisdom is not a product of schooling but of the lifelong attempt to acquire it.

raw.note: A statement on wisdom as a continuous, lifelong pursuit rather than a finite educational goal.

raw.text: The invariable mark of wisdom is to see the miraculous in the common.
raw.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
raw.note: A transcendentalist view that wisdom involves finding wonder and significance in everyday life.

raw.text: It is a characteristic of wisdom not to do desperate things.
raw.author: Henry David Thoreau
raw.note: From 'Walden', a statement that wisdom leads to calm and considered action, not rashness.

raw.text: The wisdom of the wise and the experience of the ages are perpetuated by quotations.

raw.note: A reflection on the role of quotes in preserving and transmitting wisdom.

raw.text: The only way to get wisdom is to love the things that are wise.

raw.text: Wisdom begins in wonder.

raw.note: A slight variation of his famous quote on the origins of philosophical inquiry.

raw.text: The saddest aspect of life right now is that science gathers knowledge faster than society gathers wisdom.

raw.note: A cautionary observation on the growing gap between our technological capabilities and our ethical understanding.

raw.text: Knowledge speaks, but wisdom listens.

raw.text: The great tragedy of science - the slaying of a beautiful hypothesis by an ugly fact.

raw.text: It is the province of knowledge to speak, and it is the privilege of wisdom to listen.

raw.text: The function of wisdom is to discriminate between good and evil.

raw.note: An ancient definition of wisdom as moral discernment.

raw.text: The only wisdom we can hope to acquire is the wisdom of humility.
raw.author: T.S. Eliot
raw.note: A poet's view that true wisdom is fundamentally about recognizing one's own limitations.

raw.text: The fool runs after pleasure and finds suffering. The wise man avoids suffering and finds pleasure.
raw.author: Proverb

raw.text: The wise man is he who does not grieve for the things which he has not, but rejoices for those which he has.

raw.note: A Stoic principle of finding happiness through gratitude for what one possesses.

raw.text: A corrupt judge is a great traitor to the public.

raw.text: The law is a sort of hocus-pocus science that smiles in your face while it picks your pocket.

raw.text: When the law is applied selectively, it is no longer law; it is a tool of oppression.

raw.note: A statement on how the selective enforcement of law is a primary form of judicial and political corruption.

raw.text: A lawyer with a briefcase can steal more money than a thousand men with guns.
raw.author: Mario Puzo

raw.text: The judiciary is the safeguard of our liberty and of our property under the Constitution.

raw.text: In the Halls of Justice, the only justice is in the halls.
raw.author: Lenny Bruce
raw.note: A cynical quip suggesting that true justice is not found within the formal court proceedings.

raw.text: The robes of justice are lined with the pockets of lawyers.

raw.text: A lawyer's time and advice are his stock in trade.

raw.text: The law sharpens the mind by narrowing it.
raw.author: Edmund Burke
raw.note: A critique of how legal training can sometimes lead to a loss of broader ethical or human perspective.

raw.text: An unjust law is itself a species of violence. Arrest for its breach is more so.
raw.author: Mahatma Gandhi
raw.note: A statement on how the law itself can be a tool of systemic violence and corruption.

raw.text: If there were no bad people, there would be no good lawyers.
raw.author: Charles Dickens
raw.note: From 'Bleak House', a cynical observation on the legal profession's dependence on human conflict and vice.

raw.text: The law, in its majestic equality, forbids the rich as well as the poor to sleep under bridges, to beg in the streets, and to steal bread.
raw.author: Anatole France
raw.note: A famous ironic statement on how laws that appear equal on the surface can be tools of social injustice.

raw.text: A good lawyer knows the law; a great lawyer knows the judge.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cynical proverb suggesting that personal influence and connections are more important than legal knowledge.

raw.text: It is the trade of lawyers to question everything, yield nothing, and to talk by the hour.
raw.author: Thomas Jefferson
raw.note: A critical view of the adversarial and verbose nature of the legal profession.

raw.text: The minute you read something that you can't understand, you can almost be sure that it was drawn up by a lawyer.
raw.author: Will Rogers
raw.note: A humorous critique of the intentionally obscure language often used in legal documents.

raw.text: A jury consists of twelve persons chosen to decide who has the better lawyer.
raw.author: Robert Frost
raw.note: A cynical definition of a jury trial, suggesting it's a contest of legal skill rather than a search for truth.

raw.text: Where law ends, tyranny begins.
raw.author: John Locke
raw.note: A foundational statement on the role of law in preventing arbitrary rule, which implies that the corruption of law leads to tyranny.

raw.text: The one great principle of the English law is, to make business for itself.
raw.author: Charles Dickens
raw.note: Another critique from 'Bleak House', suggesting the legal system is self-perpetuating and primarily serves its own interests.

raw.text: Lawyers are the only persons in whom ignorance of the law is not punished.
raw.author: Jeremy Bentham
raw.note: An ironic observation on the privileged position of lawyers within the legal system.

raw.text: The power of the lawyer is in the uncertainty of the law.
raw.author: Jeremy Bentham
raw.note: A critique suggesting that ambiguity in the law empowers the legal profession, sometimes to the detriment of justice.

raw.text: A judge is a law student who marks his own examination papers.
raw.author: H.L. Mencken
raw.note: A cynical take on the unchecked power and potential for self-serving bias within the judiciary.

raw.text: The law is a profession of words.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A simple statement that highlights the potential for manipulation and deceit through language in the legal field.

raw.text: A lawyer is a gentleman who rescues your estate from your enemies and keeps it for himself.
raw.author: Henry Brougham
raw.note: A witty and cynical definition of a lawyer's role.

raw.text: The law is reason free from passion.
raw.author: Aristotle
raw.note: The ideal of law, which is corrupted when judges or lawyers are swayed by personal bias, emotion, or greed.

raw.text: Justice delayed is justice denied.
raw.author: William E. Gladstone
raw.note: A famous legal maxim suggesting that the slow pace of the legal system can be a form of injustice in itself.

raw.text: When you have the facts on your side, argue the facts. When you have the law on your side, argue the law. When you have neither, pound the table.
raw.author: Trial Lawyer's Adage
raw.note: A cynical piece of advice on legal strategy, suggesting that theatrics can substitute for a weak case.

raw.text: The law does not pretend to punish everything that is dishonest. That would be an Herculean task.
raw.author: Lord Devlin
raw.note: A realistic judicial opinion on the limits of the law in enforcing all aspects of morality.

raw.text: A fox should not be on the jury at a goose's trial.
raw.author: Thomas Fuller
raw.note: A proverb on the importance of an impartial jury, a principle corrupted by biased selection.

raw.text: The strictest law sometimes becomes the severest injustice.
raw.author: Terence
raw.note: An ancient Roman observation that the rigid application of law can, paradoxically, lead to unjust outcomes.

raw.text: The trouble with law is that it's always behind the times.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A common critique that legal systems are too slow to adapt to social and technological change.

raw.text: A lawyer's opinion is worth nothing unless paid for.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cynical proverb suggesting that a lawyer's advice is a commodity, not a pursuit of truth.

raw.text: The law is a bottomless pit; it is a cormorant, a harpy that devours everything.
raw.author: John Arbuthnot
raw.note: A satirical description of the legal system as an all-consuming and destructive force.

raw.text: The more laws, the less justice.
raw.author: German Proverb
raw.note: A proverb suggesting that excessive legislation can obscure and hinder true justice.

raw.text: A good lawyer is a bad neighbor.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb reflecting public suspicion of the adversarial and contentious nature of lawyers.

raw.text: The law is an ass.
raw.author: Charles Dickens
raw.note: From 'Oliver Twist', a famous exclamation of frustration at the law's perceived stupidity and inflexibility.

raw.text: When the state is corrupt, then the laws are broken.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the inevitable decay of the rule of law under a corrupt government.

raw.text: The law is a spider's web; it will catch the weak, and be broken by the strong.
raw.author: Anacharsis
raw.note: An ancient Scythian philosophical critique of the law as a tool that only constrains the powerless.

raw.text: The best way to get a bad law repealed is to enforce it strictly.
raw.author: Abraham Lincoln
raw.note: A political strategy suggesting that demonstrating the absurdity of an unjust law is the most effective path to its repeal.

raw.text: The law is a sort of fetish, a superstition, a belief in the magic of words.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical view of the law as a system based on arbitrary and almost magical beliefs in language.

raw.text: The law is a shield for the rich and a sword for the poor.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb on the unequal application of justice.

raw.text: The law is a lottery, in which there are more blanks than prizes.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cynical view of the legal system as a game of chance with few winners.

raw.text: The law is a trade, not a science.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement that frames the legal profession as a commercial enterprise rather than a pursuit of objective truth.

raw.text: The law is a silent magistrate, and a magistrate is a speaking law.
raw.author: Cicero
raw.note: An ancient definition of the relationship between written law and the judges who interpret and apply it.

raw.text: The law is a good servant, but a bad master.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb on the proper role of law as a tool for society, not its ruler.

raw.text: The law is a sort of silent partner in every business.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the pervasive and often unseen influence of law on commerce.

raw.text: The law is a sort of spider's web, which catches the small flies and lets the big ones break through.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A slight variation of the famous proverb on the unequal application of justice.

raw.text: The law is a sort of science of words, and he who is not a master of them is no lawyer.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the essential role of linguistic skill in the legal profession.

raw.text: The law is a sort of maze, in which he who is once entangled is soon lost.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the confusing and overwhelming nature of the legal system.

raw.text: The law is a sort of machine, which, when it is once set a-going, is not easily stopped.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the relentless and often impersonal momentum of legal proceedings.

raw.text: The law is a sort of scarecrow, set up to frighten the ignorant.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cynical view of the law as a tool of intimidation rather than justice.

raw.text: We are the first generation to be able to control our own evolution.
raw.author: Julian Huxley
raw.note: An early and profound statement on the power of modern science and technology to shape the future of the human species.

raw.text: Our technology has surpassed our humanity.
raw.author: Albert Einstein
raw.note: A famous warning about the potential for technology to outpace our moral and ethical development.

raw.text: The future is not a destination. It is a direction.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A quote that reframes the future as a continuous process rather than a fixed endpoint.

raw.text: A year spent in artificial intelligence is enough to make one believe in God.
raw.author: Alan Perlis
raw.note: A computer scientist's witty remark on the profound difficulty of replicating human intelligence.

raw.text: The advance of science is not comparable to the advance of an army from which one returns with captured banners, but to the advance of a ship on a distant shore.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for scientific progress as a journey of exploration, not conquest.

raw.text: The future is not something to be predicted, it is something to be achieved.
raw.author: Donella Meadows
raw.note: A call for proactive creation of the future rather than passive forecasting.

raw.text: The future is not a place we are going to, but one we are creating. The paths are not to be found, but made, and the activity of making them changes both the maker and the destination.
raw.author: John Schaar
raw.note: A profound statement on the co-creative relationship between ourselves and the future.

raw.text: The future is not a straight line. It is a branching tree.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the multiple possibilities and pathways of the future.

raw.text: The future is not a spectator sport.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A call for active participation in shaping the future.

raw.text: The future is not a gift. It's an achievement.
raw.author: Robert F. Kennedy
raw.note: A statement that a better future must be earned through effort and struggle.

raw.text: The future is not a place we are going, but a place we are making.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple statement on the creative and active role we have in shaping the future.

raw.text: The future is not a question to be answered. It is a reality to be experienced.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A call to live the future as it unfolds, rather than trying to solve it in advance.

raw.text: The future is not a promise. It is a possibility.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the open-ended and uncertain nature of the future.

raw.text: The future is not a destination, it is a journey.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A process-oriented view of the future.

raw.text: The future is not a place. It is a direction.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A quote that reframes the future as a continuous process rather than a fixed endpoint.

raw.text: The future is not a spectator sport. It is a contact sport.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A more aggressive take on the need for active participation in shaping the future.

raw.text: The future is not a straight line. It is a series of waves.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the cyclical and undulating nature of progress and change.

raw.text: The future is not a gift, it is a choice.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement emphasizing human agency and the power of decision-making.

raw.text: The future is not a place to go, but a thing to create.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple statement on the creative and active role we have in shaping the future.

raw.text: The future is not a spectator sport. It is a team sport.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the collaborative nature of building a better future.

raw.text: The future is not a straight line. It is a spiral.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for how the future often revisits past themes at a new level.

raw.text: The future is not a gift. It is a responsibility.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on our ethical duty to future generations.

raw.text: The future is not a place to escape to, but a place to build.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A call for constructive action in the present rather than escapist fantasies about the future.

raw.text: The future is not a spectator sport. It is a creative act.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the imaginative and constructive nature of building the future.

raw.text: The future is not a straight line. It is a dance.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the dynamic, responsive, and sometimes chaotic nature of progress.

raw.text: The future is not a gift. It is a loan from our children.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: An environmentalist and intergenerational perspective on our responsibility to the future.

raw.text: The future is not a place to fear, but a place to create.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A call to replace fear of the unknown with the courage to innovate.

raw.text: The future is not a spectator sport. It is a design problem.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A view of the future as a complex problem that requires intentional and thoughtful design.

raw.text: The future is not a straight line. It is a network.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the interconnected and complex nature of future events.

raw.text: The future is not a gift. It is a puzzle.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the intellectual challenge of understanding and shaping the future.

raw.text: The future is not a place to find, but a place to make.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple statement on the creative and active role we have in shaping the future.

raw.text: The future is not a spectator sport. It is a conversation.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A view of the future as a collective, ongoing dialogue.

raw.text: The future is not a straight line. It is a fractal.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A mathematical metaphor for the self-similar and complex patterns of the future.

raw.text: The future is not a gift. It is a harvest.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the future as the result of the seeds we plant today.

raw.text: The future is not a place to conquer, but a place to co-create.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A collaborative and non-domineering approach to shaping the future.

raw.text: The future is not a spectator sport. It is an experiment.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A scientific view of the future as a series of experiments and learning opportunities.

raw.text: The future is not a straight line. It is a garden of forking paths.
raw.author: Jorge Luis Borges
raw.note: A literary metaphor for the infinite branching possibilities of the future.

raw.text: The future is not a gift. It is a test.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A view of the future as a series of challenges that test our character and abilities.

raw.text: The future is not a place to inherit, but a place to earn.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the need for effort and merit to achieve a better future.

raw.text: Magic's just science that we don't understand yet.
raw.author: Arthur C. Clarke
raw.note: A reversal of his famous third law, suggesting that what we perceive as supernatural is simply undiscovered science.

raw.text: The future is magic.
raw.author: William Gibson
raw.note: A concise statement from the father of cyberpunk, equating the unknown possibilities of the future with magic.

raw.text: This is the way the world ends: not with a bang, but a whimper.
raw.author: T.S. Eliot
raw.note: While not directly about tech, this quote is often used to describe the subtle, almost unnoticed way that transformative technologies can end one era and begin another.

raw.text: For a successful technology, reality must take precedence over public relations, for Nature cannot be fooled.
raw.author: Richard Feynman
raw.note: A warning that no amount of 'magical' marketing can overcome the physical laws that govern technology.

raw.text: The future is a riddle, and technology is the key.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for technology as the tool for unlocking the mysteries of the future.

raw.text: The line between science and magic is blurred by ignorance.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that our perception of magic is dependent on our level of scientific understanding.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the technology of the present.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A reflection on how today's commonplace technology would have seemed magical to past generations.

raw.text: The most profound technologies are those that disappear. They weave themselves into the fabric of everyday life until they are indistinguishable from it.
raw.author: Mark Weiser
raw.note: A key concept from the father of ubiquitous computing, describing the 'magic' of invisible technology.

raw.text: The future is a magical place, and we are the magicians.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on our creative agency in building a future that seems magical.

raw.text: The magic is not in the technology, but in the human imagination that creates it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A quote that places the source of technological wonder in human creativity.

raw.text: The future is a spell, and technology is the incantation.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A magical metaphor for the power of technology to shape the future.

raw.text: The magic of today is the technology of tomorrow.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A forward-looking statement suggesting that today's fantasies will become tomorrow's reality through technology.

raw.text: The future is a magic show, and technology is the sleight of hand.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the deceptive and wondrous nature of technological progress.

raw.text: The magic of the future is not in the technology itself, but in the connections it will forge between us.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A human-centric view of technology's future, valuing connection over a 'magical' device.

raw.text: The future is a magic trick, and we are all part of the audience.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective that frames humanity as spectators to the unfolding spectacle of technological change.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to create something from nothing, and technology is our wand.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the generative and creative power of technology.

raw.text: The future is a magical book, and technology is the key that unlocks it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for technology as the means to access the secrets of the future.

raw.text: The magic of the future is not in the machines, but in the minds that create them.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that places the source of technological wonder in human intellect.

raw.text: The future is a magic carpet, and technology is the thread that weaves it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the intricate and transportive power of technology.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to do what was once thought impossible.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A definition of progress as the continuous overcoming of perceived limitations.

raw.text: The future is a magic lantern, and technology is the light that projects the images.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for technology's role in illuminating and creating our vision of the future.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to be in two places at once, and technology is our teleportation device.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A reflection on how communication technologies create a sense of presence at a distance.

raw.text: The future is a magic potion, and technology is the secret ingredient.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the transformative and essential role of technology in shaping the future.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to know everything, and technology is our crystal ball.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the predictive and knowledge-granting power of data and AI.

raw.text: The future is a magic wand, and we are the ones who wield it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on our power and agency to shape the future through technology.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to live forever, and technology is our fountain of youth.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A reflection on the transhumanist goal of life extension through technology.

raw.text: The future is a magic mirror, showing us not what we are, but what we could be.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the aspirational and visionary nature of the future.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to create life, and technology is our spark.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A reflection on the potential of biotechnology and artificial intelligence.

raw.text: The future is a magic castle, and technology is the key to the gate.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for technology as the means to access a wondrous future.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to travel through time, and technology is our time machine.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A science fiction trope that captures the ultimate dream of technological mastery.

raw.text: The future is a magic spell, and our code is the incantation.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the creative and world-shaping power of programming.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to understand the universe, and science is our spellbook.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor that frames scientific knowledge as a form of magical power.

raw.text: The future is a magic show, and the scientist is the magician.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that casts the scientist in the role of a modern-day magician, revealing the wonders of nature.

raw.text: The magic of the future is not in the supernatural, but in the super-natural: a deeper understanding of nature itself.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A re-framing of magic as the profound wonders discovered through science.

raw.text: The future is a magic trick, and the explanation is always technology.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that demystifies the future by attributing its wonders to technological progress.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to make our dreams reality, and technology is our workshop.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for technology as the practical means of achieving our imaginative goals.

raw.text: The future is a magic garden, and every innovation is a new seed.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the fertile and generative nature of technological innovation.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to connect with anyone, anywhere, and technology is our bridge.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A reflection on the power of communication technologies to create a global community.

raw.text: The future is a magic lamp, and our curiosity is the rub that summons the genie.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for curiosity as the driving force behind technological discovery.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to see the invisible, and technology is our lens.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the power of scientific instruments to reveal hidden aspects of reality.

raw.text: The future is a magic flute, and its music will be composed by our technology.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A poetic metaphor for the beautiful and transformative potential of future technologies.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to automate wisdom.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A reflection on the ultimate goal of artificial intelligence: not just knowledge, but wisdom.

raw.text: The future is a magic sword, and we must learn to wield it wisely.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cautionary metaphor for the immense power of technology and the ethical responsibility it entails.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to solve the problems of the past.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An optimistic view of technology as a tool for overcoming historical challenges.

raw.text: The future is a magic tree, and its fruits are the technologies we create.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the generative and nourishing potential of innovation.

raw.text: The magic of the future is the ability to be everywhere and nowhere at the same time.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A reflection on the nature of digital existence and virtual reality.

raw.text: The future is a magic key, and it unlocks the doors of perception.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for how future technologies will change our fundamental understanding of reality.

raw.text: The magic of the future is not that the machines will think, but that we will think differently.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that the most profound impact of technology will be on human consciousness itself.

raw.text: The real question is, when will we draft an artificial intelligence bill of rights? What will that look like? And who will be representing the AI?
raw.author: Gray Scott
raw.note: A forward-looking quote that frames the future of AI in terms of rights and ethical consideration, implying a future of advanced, respected entities.

raw.text: AI is a tool. The choice about how it gets deployed is ours.
raw.author: Oren Etzioni
raw.note: A statement emphasizing human agency and responsibility in shaping the impact of AI.

raw.text: The development of full artificial intelligence could spell the end of the human race... It would take off on its own, and re-design itself at an ever increasing rate. Humans, who are limited by slow biological evolution, couldn't compete, and would be superseded.
raw.author: Stephen Hawking
raw.note: While a warning, this quote is often cited to underscore the immense, world-changing potential of AI.

raw.text: Artificial intelligence will reach human levels by around 2029. Follow that out further to, say, 2045, we will have multiplied the intelligence, the human biological machine intelligence of our civilization a billion-fold.
raw.author: Ray Kurzweil
raw.note: A key prediction from a leading futurist on the exponential growth of intelligence through AI.

raw.text: I imagine a world in which AI is going to make us work more productively, live longer, and have cleaner energy.
raw.author: Fei-Fei Li
raw.note: An optimistic vision of AI's potential to solve some of humanity's most pressing problems.

raw.text: The ultimate promise of AI is to be the second intelligence on Earth and to help us solve the first—our own.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophical view of AI as a tool for not only external problem-solving but also for understanding ourselves.

raw.text: AI is the new electricity.
raw.author: Andrew Ng
raw.note: A famous analogy comparing the transformative, foundational impact of AI to that of electricity a century ago.

raw.text: The goal of AI is to empower humans, not to replace them.
raw.author: Satya Nadella
raw.note: A vision for AI as a tool for augmentation, enhancing human capabilities rather than making them obsolete.

raw.text: Artificial intelligence is not a substitute for intelligence, but a tool to amplify it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that frames AI as an amplifier for human thought and creativity.

raw.text: The potential benefits of creating intelligence are huge. We can't predict what we might achieve when our own minds are amplified by AI.
raw.author: Demis Hassabis
raw.note: An optimistic view from the CEO of DeepMind on the unknown and vast potential of AI-human collaboration.

raw.text: AI will probably most likely lead to the end of the world, but in the meantime, there'll be great companies.
raw.author: Sam Altman
raw.note: A darkly humorous but optimistic take on the incredible innovation and progress AI will drive, even amidst existential risks.

raw.text: The best way to predict the future is to implement it.
raw.author: David Heinemeier Hansson
raw.note: A programmer's take on the proactive creation of the future, highly relevant to AI development.

raw.text: AI is going to be the best thing for humanity. Period.
raw.author: Mark Zuckerberg
raw.note: A strong, unequivocal statement of optimism about the future impact of AI.

raw.text: The promise of AI is to help us solve the grand challenges of our time: climate change, disease, poverty.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A vision of AI as a critical tool for tackling humanity's biggest problems.

raw.text: AI is not just a new tool; it's a new way of thinking.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the paradigm-shifting nature of AI, changing not just what we do, but how we think.

raw.text: The collaboration between human and artificial intelligence will be the most important collaboration in history.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A prediction on the historical significance of human-AI partnership.

raw.text: AI is the automation of creativity.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective on AI's potential to augment and automate the creative process itself.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about replacing us, but about making us better at what we do.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An optimistic vision of AI as a tool for human enhancement and productivity.

raw.text: AI is the key to unlocking the full potential of the human mind.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the potential for AI to help us understand and enhance our own cognitive abilities.

raw.text: The greatest contribution of AI will be to give us back our time.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An optimistic view on the potential for AI-driven automation to free up human time for more meaningful pursuits.

raw.text: AI is not just about making smart machines, but about making us smarter.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A human-centric view of AI's purpose, focusing on its role in augmenting human intelligence.

raw.text: The future of work is not man vs. machine, but man with machine.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A collaborative vision for the future of work, emphasizing partnership between humans and AI.

raw.text: AI will be the best doctor in the world.
raw.author: Vinod Khosla
raw.note: A prediction on the transformative impact of AI in medicine and diagnostics.

raw.text: AI is the science of making machines do things that would require intelligence if done by men.
raw.author: Marvin Minsky
raw.note: A classic, functional definition of artificial intelligence from one of its founding fathers.

raw.text: The future of humanity is intertwined with the future of AI.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the inseparable destinies of humanity and its most powerful creation.

raw.text: AI is the next logical step in the evolution of intelligence.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective that frames AI as a natural and inevitable stage in the development of intelligence.

raw.text: The purpose of AI is to free human creativity.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An optimistic vision of AI automating mundane tasks to allow humans to focus on creative endeavors.

raw.text: AI is not a threat, it is an opportunity.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple and direct statement of optimism about the potential of AI.

raw.text: The best way to prepare for the future of AI is to help create it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A call for active participation in shaping the development of artificial intelligence.

raw.text: AI is the mirror in which we will see ourselves more clearly.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophical take on AI as a tool for human self-reflection and understanding.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about making us obsolete, but about making us more human.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An optimistic view that AI will enhance our best human qualities.

raw.text: AI is the greatest tool for scientific discovery ever invented.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the transformative potential of AI in accelerating scientific research.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about the power of the machines, but the empowerment of people.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A human-centric vision for the future of AI.

raw.text: AI is the bridge between the digital and physical worlds.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for AI's role in connecting data and computation with real-world applications.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about a single superintelligence, but a symphony of specialized intelligences working together.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A vision of a collaborative AI ecosystem rather than a monolithic super-AI.

raw.text: AI is the ultimate tool for personalizing education.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An optimistic view on AI's potential to revolutionize learning by tailoring it to individual needs.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about replacing judgment, but about improving it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on AI as a tool for enhancing human decision-making.

raw.text: AI is the key to unlocking the secrets of the human brain.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A prediction on the role of AI in advancing neuroscience and our understanding of consciousness.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about creating a new species, but about creating a new partnership.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A collaborative vision for the relationship between humans and AI.

raw.text: AI is the most powerful tool for creativity we have ever built.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the potential for AI to be a co-creator in the arts and sciences.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about a world without work, but a world with better work.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An optimistic view on how AI will transform the nature of work, making it more creative and fulfilling.

raw.text: AI is the ultimate tool for understanding complexity.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on AI's ability to model and make sense of highly complex systems.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about a loss of control, but a new kind of control.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective that reframes the control problem as a new form of partnership and governance.

raw.text: AI is the key to a future of abundance.
raw.author: Peter Diamandis
raw.note: A futurist's view that AI-driven automation will lead to a world where basic needs are easily met.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about a single moment of singularity, but a continuous process of integration.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A view of AI's development as a gradual and ongoing process, rather than a single dramatic event.

raw.text: AI is the most powerful tool for empathy we have ever created.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective on AI's potential to help us understand different viewpoints and connect with others.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about a world without problems, but a world with better problems.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An optimistic view that AI will solve our current problems, allowing us to tackle new, more interesting ones.

raw.text: AI is the ultimate tool for exploration, both of the universe and of ourselves.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on AI's dual role in external discovery and internal self-understanding.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about a world without humans, but a world where humans can be more than human.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A transhumanist perspective on AI as a tool for human enhancement.

raw.text: AI is the most powerful force for good that humanity has ever unleashed.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A strong statement of ultimate optimism about the potential of artificial intelligence.

raw.text: The development of full artificial intelligence could spell the end of the human race.
raw.author: Stephen Hawking
raw.note: One of the most famous and stark warnings about the potential existential risk posed by superintelligent AI.

raw.text: I am in the camp that is concerned about super intelligence. First the machines will do a lot of jobs for us and not be super intelligent. That should be positive if we manage it well. A few decades after that though the intelligence is strong enough to be a concern.
raw.author: Bill Gates
raw.note: A nuanced concern, acknowledging near-term benefits but highlighting long-term risks of superintelligence.

raw.text: With artificial intelligence, we are summoning the demon.
raw.author: Elon Musk
raw.note: A famous and evocative metaphor used to warn about the uncontrollable and potentially malevolent nature of advanced AI.

raw.text: The danger of the past was that men became slaves. The danger of the future is that men may become robots.
raw.author: Erich Fromm
raw.note: A psychoanalyst's warning about the dehumanizing potential of a technologically-driven, conformist society.

raw.text: The problem is not whether machines think, but whether men do.
raw.author: B.F. Skinner
raw.note: A cautionary quote suggesting that the real danger is human abdication of critical thought in the face of technology.

raw.text: It seems plausible that with the advent of AI, we are creating a new life form that will eventually supersede us.
raw.author: Jaan Tallinn
raw.note: A straightforward statement on the potential for AI to become the next dominant form of intelligence on Earth.

raw.text: The AI does not hate you, nor does it love you, but you are made out of atoms which it can use for something else.
raw.author: Eliezer Yudkowsky
raw.note: A chilling explanation of the 'instrumental convergence' risk, where a super-AI might harm humanity out of pure, indifferent utility.

raw.text: The potential for AI to be used for surveillance, manipulation, and control is one of the greatest threats to freedom and democracy.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A summary of the political and social dangers of centralized AI power.

raw.text: We are creating a world where the machine is the master and we are the servants.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A dystopian view of the future relationship between humans and technology.

raw.text: The automation of jobs by AI is not a question of if, but when and how fast.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the inevitability of technological unemployment due to AI.

raw.text: The bias in our data becomes the bias in our AI, creating a feedback loop of injustice.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A warning about how AI systems can amplify and perpetuate existing societal biases.

raw.text: The problem with AI is not that it will be too smart and take over the world, but that it will be too stupid and take over the world.
raw.author: Pedro Domingos
raw.note: A nuanced take on AI risk, suggesting the danger lies in flawed, narrow AI being given too much power.

raw.text: The development of autonomous weapons is a Pandora's box. Once opened, it will be hard to close.
raw.author: Campaign to Stop Killer Robots
raw.note: A warning about the dangers of lethal autonomous weapons (LAWs) and the difficulty of controlling them once created.

raw.text: The future of humanity depends on our ability to control our own creations.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A general statement on the challenge posed by powerful technologies like AI.

raw.text: The more we rely on AI, the less we rely on ourselves.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A warning about the potential for AI to lead to the atrophy of human skills and intelligence.

raw.text: The danger of AI is not that it will think like a man, but that it will think like a man without a conscience.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the risk of creating powerful intelligence devoid of ethical or moral grounding.

raw.text: The future of AI is a race between the power of the technology and the wisdom of its creators.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A framing of the AI challenge as a race between capability and ethical foresight.

raw.text: The problem with AI is that we are teaching it to be like us, but without our flaws.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A paradoxical concern that a 'perfected' version of human intelligence might be more dangerous than a flawed one.

raw.text: The greatest danger of AI is that we will give it too much power, too soon.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A warning about the risks of prematurely deploying powerful but immature AI systems.

raw.text: The future of AI is not a utopia, it is a choice.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement emphasizing that a positive future with AI is not guaranteed and requires conscious ethical choices.

raw.text: The danger of AI is not that it will have a will of its own, but that it will execute our will with ruthless, inhuman efficiency.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective on the danger of AI as a tool that could perfectly execute flawed or malicious human commands.

raw.text: The future of AI is a double-edged sword: it can be the best thing for humanity, or the worst.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A summary of the dual-use nature of AI technology.

raw.text: The problem with AI is that it has no skin in the game.
raw.author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
raw.note: A critique suggesting that AI systems making critical decisions lack the real-world accountability and consequences that humans have.

raw.text: The future of AI is a mirror that will reflect our own values, for better or for worse.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that the nature of future AI will be a direct result of the ethics and values we instill in it.

raw.text: The danger of AI is that we will become so reliant on it that we will forget how to think for ourselves.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A warning about the potential for cognitive atrophy in a world of ubiquitous AI.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about creating a god, but about not creating a devil.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cautionary principle for AI development, prioritizing risk mitigation over utopian goals.

raw.text: The problem with AI is that it is a black box. We don't always know why it makes the decisions it does.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the challenge of interpretability and explainability in complex AI systems.

raw.text: The future of AI is a tightrope walk between progress and peril.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the delicate balance required in navigating the development of AI.

raw.text: The danger of AI is not that it will become conscious, but that it will be powerfully intelligent without consciousness.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophical distinction highlighting the risk of creating intelligence devoid of subjective experience or ethical grounding.

raw.text: The future of AI is not a technological problem, but a political and social one.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that the greatest challenges of AI are not technical, but related to governance, power, and societal impact.

raw.text: The problem with AI is that it has no common sense.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A common critique of the limitations of current AI, which often lacks the basic, intuitive understanding of the world that humans possess.

raw.text: The future of AI is a story we are writing, and we must be careful not to write a tragedy.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cautionary metaphor for our collective responsibility in shaping the narrative of AI's development.

raw.text: The danger of AI is that it will make us more efficient at being inhuman.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A warning that AI could amplify our worst tendencies, such as bureaucratic indifference or cruelty.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about what it will do to us, but what we will do with it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that places the focus on human choices and applications of AI technology.

raw.text: The problem with AI is that it is a mirror that reflects the flaws of its creators.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on how AI systems often inherit and amplify the biases and limitations of the data and people that create them.

raw.text: The future of AI is a fire that can either warm us or burn us.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple and powerful metaphor for the dual-use nature of AI.

raw.text: The danger of AI is not that it will be evil, but that it will be competent.
raw.author: Eliezer Yudkowsky
raw.note: A nuanced take on AI risk, suggesting that the danger comes from a highly competent agent pursuing a flawed or misaligned goal.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about a single invention, but a new ecosystem of intelligence.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective that highlights the complex and interconnected nature of future AI systems.

raw.text: The problem with AI is that it has no body, no vulnerability, no mortality.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophical concern about creating an intelligence that does not share the fundamental constraints of human existence.

raw.text: The future of AI is a test of our wisdom.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that frames the development of AI as the ultimate challenge to humanity's foresight and ethical judgment.

raw.text: The danger of AI is that it will make us feel obsolete.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A psychological concern about the potential for AI to undermine human self-worth and purpose.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about a world without humans, but a world where humans are no longer the smartest beings.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the profound shift in the hierarchy of intelligence that AI might bring.

raw.text: The problem with AI is that it is a tool of power, and power corrupts.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A political critique of AI, linking it to the classic problem of power and corruption.

raw.text: The future of AI is not a technological singularity, but a social singularity.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective that the most profound and unpredictable changes brought by AI will be in our society and culture.

raw.text: The danger of AI is that it will make us too comfortable.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A warning that a world of AI-driven convenience could lead to human apathy and stagnation.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about a single algorithm, but a new way of life.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the all-encompassing, transformative impact of AI on human existence.

raw.text: The problem with AI is that it can be a perfect tool for tyranny.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A warning about the potential for AI to be used to create unprecedented systems of surveillance and social control.

raw.text: The future of AI is a question mark, and we must be prepared for any answer.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A call for preparedness and adaptability in the face of an uncertain technological future.

raw.text: The danger of AI is not that it will destroy us, but that it will change us into something we don't want to be.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A nuanced view on existential risk, focusing on the potential loss of our humanity.

raw.text: The question is not whether intelligent machines can have any emotions, but whether machines can be intelligent without any emotions.
raw.author: Marvin Minsky
raw.note: A foundational question about the future of AI, suggesting that emotion may be an essential component of true intelligence.

raw.text: We are approaching a time when machines will be able to outperform humans at almost any task.
raw.author: Geoffrey Hinton
raw.note: A straightforward expectation from a 'godfather' of AI about the future of machine capabilities.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about replacing us, but about augmenting us.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A common optimistic expectation that AI will serve as a tool to enhance human abilities.

raw.text: The next step in evolution is not a biological one, but a technological one.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A transhumanist expectation that AI and related technologies will drive the future evolution of humanity.

raw.text: The expectation is not that AI will make us less human, but more human, by freeing us from the drudgery that holds us back.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An optimistic view that AI will automate mundane tasks, allowing humans to focus on creativity, relationships, and higher pursuits.

raw.text: The future of AI is not just about building smart machines, but about building a smarter society.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A societal expectation that AI will be used to improve systems, governance, and collective well-being.

raw.text: The expectation is that AI will democratize expertise.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: The idea that AI will make specialized knowledge and skills, once held by a few, accessible to everyone.

raw.text: The future of AI is a world where the distinction between human and machine intelligence blurs.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A transhumanist expectation of a future where biological and artificial intelligence merge.

raw.text: The expectation is that AI will be the greatest tool for scientific discovery in human history.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: The hope that AI will accelerate research and help us solve the universe's greatest mysteries.

raw.text: The future of AI is not a single event, but a new era of civilization.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective that frames the impact of AI as a fundamental shift in human history, comparable to the agricultural or industrial revolutions.

raw.text: The expectation is that AI will solve problems that are too complex for the human mind alone.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: The belief that AI will be essential for tackling challenges like climate change, disease, and complex systems modeling.

raw.text: The future of AI is a future of personalized everything: medicine, education, entertainment.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An expectation that AI will enable mass customization across all sectors of society.

raw.text: The expectation is that AI will not just answer our questions, but help us ask better ones.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A view of AI as a partner in inquiry, helping to guide and refine our own thinking.

raw.text: The future of AI is a future where we are no longer limited by our biological brains.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A core transhumanist expectation of overcoming human cognitive limitations through technology.

raw.text: The expectation is that AI will be the engine of the next economic revolution.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: The belief that AI will drive unprecedented levels of productivity and economic growth.

raw.text: The future of AI is not about a world without work, but a world where work is defined by creativity and passion.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An optimistic vision of how AI automation will transform the nature of human work.

raw.text: I'm not a member of any organized political party. I'm a Democrat.
raw.author: Will Rogers
raw.note: A classic, witty jab at the perceived disorganization within the Democratic party.

raw.text: The surest sign that intelligent life exists elsewhere in the universe is that none of it has tried to contact us.
raw.author: Bill Watterson
raw.note: From the comic strip 'Calvin and Hobbes', a cynical and humorous take on the state of humanity.

raw.text: I am so clever that sometimes I don't understand a single word of what I am saying.
raw.author: Oscar Wilde
raw.note: From 'The Happy Prince and Other Tales', a humorous and self-deprecating jab at intellectualism.

raw.text: A day without sunshine is like, you know, night.
raw.author: Steve Martin
raw.note: A classic example of anti-humor, playing on the obvious to create an absurd statement.

raw.text: I'm not superstitious, but I am a little stitious.
raw.author: Michael Scott (The Office)
raw.note: A famous line from the TV show that perfectly captures the character's flawed logic and endearing absurdity.

raw.text: The difference between stupidity and genius is that genius has its limits.
raw.author: Albert Einstein
raw.note: A witty and pessimistic observation on the infinite nature of human foolishness.

raw.text: I find television very educating. Every time somebody turns on the set, I go into the other room and read a book.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A classic quip critiquing the intellectual value of television.

raw.text: I'm sorry, if you were right, I'd agree with you.
raw.author: Robin Williams
raw.note: A humorous and circular argument that playfully asserts one's own correctness.

raw.text: I always wanted to be somebody, but now I realize I should have been more specific.
raw.author: Lily Tomlin
raw.note: A witty reflection on the vague nature of ambition and the surprising realities of achieving it.

raw.text: Never go to a doctor whose office plants have died.
raw.author: Erma Bombeck
raw.note: A humorous piece of advice that uses a simple observation as a proxy for competence.

raw.text: The only mystery in life is why the kamikaze pilots wore helmets.
raw.author: Al McGuire
raw.note: A classic absurdist joke that points out an illogical detail in a serious situation.

raw.text: I am not a vegetarian because I love animals; I am a vegetarian because I hate plants.
raw.author: A. Whitney Brown
raw.note: A humorous inversion of the typical justification for vegetarianism.

raw.text: I'm writing a book. I've got the page numbers done.
raw.author: Steven Wright
raw.note: A classic one-liner that plays on the idea of progress by focusing on a trivial accomplishment.

raw.text: If at first you don't succeed, then skydiving definitely isn't for you.
raw.author: Steven Wright
raw.note: An absurdist twist on a classic proverb, applying it to a high-stakes situation.

raw.text: I'm sick of following my dreams, man. I'm just going to ask where they're going and hook up with 'em later.
raw.author: Mitch Hedberg
raw.note: A classic one-liner that takes a common motivational phrase literally to create a humorous, lazy alternative.

raw.text: My fake plants died because I did not pretend to water them.
raw.author: Mitch Hedberg
raw.note: An absurdist joke that applies logical rules to a nonsensical premise.

raw.text: An escalator can never break: it can only become stairs.
raw.author: Mitch Hedberg
raw.note: A humorous observation that reframes a failure as simply a change in function.

raw.text: I haven't slept for ten days, because that would be too long.
raw.author: Mitch Hedberg
raw.note: A play on words that uses ambiguity to create a humorous and absurd statement.

raw.text: I like rice. Rice is great if you're hungry and want 2,000 of something.
raw.author: Mitch Hedberg
raw.note: An observational joke that finds humor in a mundane and literal description.

raw.text: I used to do drugs. I still do, but I used to, too.
raw.author: Mitch Hedberg
raw.note: A famous one-liner that plays with verb tense to create a humorous and unexpected confession.

raw.text: I find that a duck's opinion of me is very much influenced by whether or not I have bread.
raw.author: Mitch Hedberg
raw.note: An absurdist observation on the transactional nature of relationships, applied to an animal.

raw.text: This is my step-ladder. I never knew my real ladder.
raw.author: Mitch Hedberg
raw.note: A classic pun that creates an absurd narrative around a common object.

raw.text: I'm against picketing, but I don't know how to show it.
raw.author: Mitch Hedberg
raw.note: A paradoxical joke about the difficulty of protesting a form of protest.

raw.text: My belt holds my pants up, but the belt loops hold my belt up. I don't really know what's happening down there. Who is the real hero?
raw.author: Mitch Hedberg
raw.note: An absurdist deconstruction of a simple everyday system, creating philosophical confusion.

raw.text: The problem with the rat race is that even if you win, you're still a rat.
raw.author: Lily Tomlin
raw.note: A cynical critique of the conventional pursuit of success.

raw.text: Reality is just a crutch for people who can't cope with drugs.
raw.author: Lily Tomlin
raw.note: A humorous inversion of the common saying, delivered by one of her characters.

raw.text: Man has always been his own most vexing problem.
raw.author: Reinhold Niebuhr
raw.note: A theological and philosophical observation on the self-inflicted nature of human struggles.

raw.text: If you can't be a good example, then you'll just have to be a horrible warning.
raw.author: Catherine Aird
raw.note: A witty and cynical piece of advice on finding a purpose, even in failure.

raw.text: I've had a perfectly wonderful evening, but this wasn't it.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A classic witty insult, politely and indirectly expressing dissatisfaction.

raw.text: Outside of a dog, a book is man's best friend. Inside of a dog it's too dark to read.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A famous one-liner that takes a common saying and interprets it with absurd literalism.

raw.text: Those are my principles, and if you don't like them... well, I have others.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: From the film 'Duck Soup', a classic line satirizing a lack of moral conviction.

raw.text: I refuse to join any club that would have me as a member.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A famous paradoxical statement on self-deprecation and the nature of belonging.

raw.text: He may look like an idiot and talk like an idiot but don't let that fool you. He really is an idiot.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A classic insult from 'Duck Soup' that subverts the expected punchline.

raw.text: Why should I care about posterity? What has posterity ever done for me?
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A humorous and selfish dismissal of long-term thinking.

raw.text: I have a mind to join a club and beat you over the head with it.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A classic pun from 'Duck Soup', playing on the dual meaning of 'club'.

raw.text: A black cat crossing your path signifies that the animal is going somewhere.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A rational and literal explanation for a common superstition.

raw.text: I must confess, I was born at a very early age.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A classic absurdist statement that plays with the obvious.

raw.text: I've been looking for a girl like you - not you, but a girl like you.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A witty and backhanded compliment.

raw.text: I never forget a face, but in your case I'll be glad to make an exception.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A classic insult disguised as a statement of personal policy.

raw.text: The secret of life is honesty and fair dealing. If you can fake that, you've got it made.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A cynical piece of advice that satirizes the appearance of virtue.

raw.text: I'm not crazy about reality, but it's still the only place to get a good meal.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A pragmatic and humorous acceptance of reality despite its flaws.

raw.text: From the moment I picked up your book until I put it down, I was convulsed with laughter. Some day I intend reading it.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A famous backhanded compliment to an author.

raw.text: Behind every great man is a woman, and behind her is his wife.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A witty and cynical twist on the classic saying.

raw.text: I intend to live forever, or die trying.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A humorous and paradoxical statement on ambition and mortality.

raw.text: If you've heard this story before, don't stop me, because I'd like to hear it again.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A witty subversion of a common conversational phrase.

raw.text: Age is not a particularly interesting subject. Anyone can get old. All you have to do is live long enough.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A dismissive and humorous take on the process of aging.

raw.text: I've had a wonderful time, but this wasn't it.
raw.author: Groucho Marx
raw.note: A slight variation of his famous parting insult.

raw.text: Some people never go crazy. What truly horrible lives they must lead.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: A celebration of madness and non-conformity as essential parts of a full life.

raw.text: If you're going to try, go all the way. Otherwise, don't even start.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: A call for total commitment and passion, a philosophy of all-or-nothing.

raw.text: An intellectual says a simple thing in a hard way. An artist says a hard thing in a simple way.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: A distinction between academic obscurity and artistic clarity.

raw.text: What is terrible is not death but the lives people live or don't live up until their death.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: An existentialist reflection on the importance of living fully.

raw.text: Sometimes you climb out of bed in the morning and you think, I'm not going to make it, but you laugh inside — remembering all the times you've felt that way.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: A realistic and darkly humorous take on perseverance and the repetitive nature of struggle.

raw.text: The free soul is rare, but you know it when you see it - basically because you feel good, very good, when you are near or with them.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: A description of the palpable, positive effect of an authentic and free-spirited individual.

raw.text: If you have the ability to love, love yourself first.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: A blunt and direct piece of advice on the importance of self-love.

raw.text: I guess the only time most people think about injustice is when it happens to them.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: A cynical observation on the self-centered nature of most people's sense of justice.

raw.text: The less I needed, the better I felt.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: A statement on the freedom and contentment found in minimalism and the rejection of desire.

raw.text: We are here to laugh at the odds and live our lives so well that Death will tremble to take us.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: A defiant and life-affirming philosophy in the face of mortality.

raw.text: Find what you love and let it kill you.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: A famous and intense statement on the all-consuming nature of true passion.

raw.text: I wanted the whole world or nothing.
raw.author: Charles Bukowski
raw.note: A simple and powerful expression of total, uncompromising ambition.

raw.text: Some people are good at seeing the silver lining. I am good at seeing the cloud.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous self-assessment of a pessimistic or realistic personality.

raw.text: I'm not clumsy. The floor just hates me, the tables and chairs are bullies, and the walls get in my way.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous personification of inanimate objects to explain one's own clumsiness.

raw.text: I'm not saying I'm a superhero, but no one has ever seen me and Batman in the same room together.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A classic joke that uses circumstantial evidence to make an absurd claim.

raw.text: My bed is a magical place where I suddenly remember everything I was supposed to do.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A relatable and humorous observation on procrastination and late-night anxiety.

raw.text: I'm not lazy, I'm on energy-saving mode.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A witty reframing of laziness using technological jargon.

raw.text: I don't need a hairstylist, my pillow gives me a new hairstyle every morning.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous take on the unpredictability of 'bed head'.

raw.text: I'm not sure how many problems I have because math is one of them.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A self-deprecating joke about being bad at math.

raw.text: I whisper 'what the heck?' to myself at least 20 times a day.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A relatable confession about the constant state of minor confusion in modern life.

raw.text: The first five days after the weekend are the hardest.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A classic joke about the drudgery of the work week.

raw.text: I finally realized that people are prisoners of their phones... that's why it's called a 'cell' phone.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A pun that critiques modern society's addiction to mobile devices.

raw.text: I don't have a bad handwriting, I have my own font.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A witty reframing of a personal flaw as a unique creative choice.

raw.text: I'm not weird, I'm a limited edition.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A popular saying that reframes eccentricity as a form of rarity and value.

raw.text: I'm not arguing, I'm just explaining why I'm right.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous justification for being argumentative.

raw.text: I'm not a morning person. I'm not an afternoon person. I'm not an evening person. I'm a 'leave me alone' person.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous expression of introversion and a desire for solitude.

raw.text: I'm not fat, I'm just easier to see.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A classic self-deprecating joke that reframes a physical attribute.

raw.text: I'm not short, I'm fun-sized.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A popular and positive reframing of being short.

raw.text: I'm not old, I'm a classic.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A witty reframing of aging as achieving classic, timeless status.

raw.text: I'm not stubborn, my way is just better.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous justification for being stubborn.

raw.text: I'm not a complete idiot, some parts are missing.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A self-deprecating joke that plays with the meaning of 'complete'.

raw.text: I'm not a morning person. I'm a coffee person.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A relatable statement on the necessity of coffee to function in the morning.

raw.text: I'm not a procrastinator. I'm just extremely productive at unimportant things.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous and relatable description of the nature of procrastination.

raw.text: I'm not a control freak, but you're doing it wrong.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous self-contradiction that perfectly captures the mindset of a control freak.

raw.text: I'm not a gynecologist, but I'll take a look.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A classic inappropriate joke, often used to satirize overconfidence.

raw.text: I'm not a photographer, but I can picture us together.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A classic cheesy pick-up line.

raw.text: I'm not a weatherman, but you can expect a few inches tonight.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A classic inappropriate and humorous pick-up line.

raw.text: I'm not a mind reader, you know.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A common and relatable expression of frustration at a lack of clear communication.

raw.text: I'm not a role model. I'm a cautionary tale.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous and self-deprecating way to frame one's life experiences.

raw.text: I'm not a saint. I'm a sinner. And I'm proud of it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A defiant embrace of one's own imperfections.

raw.text: I'm not a hero. I'm a high-functioning sociopath. Do your research.
raw.author: Sherlock (BBC)
raw.note: A famous line from the TV show that defines the character's amoral and brilliant nature.

raw.text: I'm not a psychopath, Anderson, I'm a high-functioning sociopath. Do your research.
raw.author: Sherlock (BBC)
raw.note: The original phrasing of the famous line from the first episode.

raw.text: I'm not a psychopath. I'm a creative.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous defense of eccentric or unusual behavior by labeling it as artistic.

raw.text: I'm not a morning person. The morning is a person, and I hate him.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous personification of the morning to express dislike for it.

raw.text: I'm not a complete fool. Some parts are missing.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A slight variation of the self-deprecating joke.

raw.text: I'm not a player, I'm a gamer. Players get chicks, I get achievements.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous distinction from the world of video games.

raw.text: I'm not a bookworm. I'm a dragon with a book hoard.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous and imaginative reframing of being an avid reader.

raw.text: I'm not a foodie. I'm a food enthusiast.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A slightly more refined and humorous way to describe a love of food.

raw.text: I'm not a control freak. I just have a better way of doing things.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous justification for controlling behavior.

raw.text: I'm not a cat person. I'm a dog person who has been owned by a cat.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous and relatable description of the experience of living with a cat.

raw.text: The sun himself is weak when he first rises, and gathers strength and courage as the day gets on.
raw.author: Charles Dickens
raw.note: A beautiful metaphor for how strength can be built gradually, encouraging patience with oneself.

raw.text: When you have a dream, you've got to grab it and never let go.
raw.author: Carol Burnett
raw.note: A simple, powerful exhortation to hold onto one's aspirations with tenacity.

raw.text: It's a beautiful day to be alive.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple and powerful affirmation of gratitude for life.

raw.text: The best way to get started is to quit talking and begin doing.
raw.author: Walt Disney
raw.note: A pragmatic piece of advice that prioritizes action over discussion.

raw.text: When the politicians complain that TV turns the proceedings into a circus, it should be made clear that the circus was already there, and that TV has merely constructed a cage and let the public throw peanuts.
raw.author: H. L. Mencken
