raw.note: A cynical take suggesting that media doesn't create political absurdity but merely exposes pre-existing corruption and foolishness.

raw.text: A politician is an animal which can sit on a fence and yet keep both ears to the ground.
raw.author: H. L. Mencken
raw.note: A humorous and cynical description of a politician's ability to be non-committal while gauging public opinion for personal gain.

raw.text: An honest politician is one who, when he is bought, will stay bought.
raw.author: Simon Cameron
raw.note: A deeply cynical definition of political integrity, implying that all politicians are for sale and loyalty is the only virtue.

raw.text: A politician thinks of the next election; a statesman, of the next generation.
raw.author: James Freeman Clarke
raw.note: A classic distinction between short-term political maneuvering and long-term, responsible leadership.

raw.text: When I was a boy I was told that anybody could become President; I'm beginning to believe it.
raw.author: Clarence Darrow
raw.note: A famous lawyer's cynical jab at the perceived lack of qualification among political leaders.

raw.text: I have come to the conclusion that politics is too serious a matter to be left to the politicians.
raw.author: Charles de Gaulle
raw.note: A statement suggesting that the political class is often inadequate to handle the weight of governance.

raw.text: The word 'politics' is derived from the word 'poly', meaning 'many', and the word 'ticks', meaning 'blood-sucking parasites'.
raw.author: Larry Hardiman
raw.note: A popular, albeit etymologically false, joke that captures public cynicism towards politicians.

raw.text: A politician will do anything to keep his job - even become a patriot.
raw.author: William Randolph Hearst
raw.note: A cynical view that politicians adopt virtuous stances out of self-preservation, not genuine belief.

raw.text: Instead of giving a politician the keys to the city, it might be better to change the locks.
raw.author: Doug Larson
raw.note: A humorous expression of distrust in political figures.

raw.text: A politician is a fellow who will lay down your life for his country.
raw.author: Texas Guinan
raw.note: A witty and cynical critique of politicians who demand sacrifice from others.

raw.text: Politics, it seems to me, for years, or all too long, has been concerned with right or left instead of right or wrong.
raw.author: Richard Armour
raw.note: A critique of partisan politics for losing its moral compass.

raw.text: The reason there are so many stupid politicians is because they think they are smart.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical take on the Dunning-Kruger effect in politics.

raw.text: A politician is a person with whose politics you don't agree; if you agree with him he's a statesman.
raw.author: David Lloyd George
raw.note: A cynical definition highlighting the subjective and partisan nature of political labels.

raw.text: The first lesson of politics is to be realistic.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that can be interpreted as a call for pragmatism or a cynical acceptance of corruption.

raw.text: A politician is a man who understands government, and it takes a politician to run a government. A statesman is a politician who's been dead 10 or 15 years.
raw.author: Harry S. Truman
raw.note: A pragmatic and humorous take on the labels we apply to political figures.

raw.text: The art of statesmanship is to foresee the inevitable and to expedite its occurrence.
raw.author: Charles Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord
raw.note: A cynical and pragmatic view of political leadership as the art of managing, rather than resisting, historical forces.

raw.text: A politician should have three hats. One for throwing into the ring, one for talking through, and one for pulling rabbits out of if elected.
raw.author: Carl Sandburg
raw.note: A metaphorical description of the different roles a politician must play: candidate, orator, and miracle-worker.

raw.text: The politician is an acrobat. He keeps his balance by saying the opposite of what he does.
raw.author: Maurice Barrès
raw.note: A cynical take on political hypocrisy.

raw.text: A politician's promise is like a shooting star, it's beautiful but it doesn't last long.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the fleeting and unreliable nature of political promises.

raw.text: A politician is a man who can be a pillar of the church on Sunday and a pillar of the saloon on Monday.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of the perceived hypocrisy and moral flexibility of politicians.

raw.text: A politician is a man who will double-cross that bridge when he comes to it.
raw.author: Oscar Levant
raw.note: A witty play on words that paints politicians as inherently treacherous.

raw.text: The politician's promises of yesterday are the taxes of today.
raw.author: William Lyon Mackenzie King
raw.note: A cynical observation on the real-world cost of political promises.

raw.text: A politician is a man who thinks of himself as a leader of the people, but is really a follower of public opinion.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of politicians as reactive and poll-driven rather than principled leaders.

raw.text: The politician's prayer: 'Lord, give me the strength to change what I can, the courage to accept what I can't, and the wisdom to know the difference... until the polls change.'
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical parody of the Serenity Prayer, applied to the perceived opportunism of politicians.

raw.text: A politician is a man who is a master of the art of telling you what you want to hear.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A definition of a politician as a panderer.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make a long story short, and then tell it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A humorous take on the verbose and often circular nature of political speech.

raw.text: A politician is a person who can find a solution for every problem, and a problem for every solution.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical view of politicians as creators of unnecessary complexity and conflict.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can say 'yes' and 'no' in the same sentence.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of the ambiguous and non-committal language used by politicians.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is on your side, even when he is on his own side.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical take on the deceptive nature of political alignment.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that the future is bright, even when the present is bleak.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of the often unrealistic optimism peddled by politicians.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of the powerful.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical observation on the populist facades often adopted by elite politicians.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a visionary, even when he is just a reactionary.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of politicians who mask regressive policies with progressive language.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of peace, even when he is a man of war.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical take on the deceptive rhetoric used to justify conflict.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of principle, even when he is a man of convenience.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of the perceived opportunism and lack of conviction among politicians.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of action, even when he is a man of inaction.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical take on the performative nature of politics, where talk often substitutes for action.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, for the people, and by the people, even when he is a man of the corporation, for the corporation, and by the corporation.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A direct critique of corporate influence in politics.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the future, even when he is a man of the past.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of politicians who use forward-looking rhetoric to mask outdated ideas.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of the party.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical observation on the conflict between representing constituents and adhering to party lines.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the law, even when he is a man above the law.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A direct critique of political hypocrisy and the abuse of power.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of the lobbyist.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of the influence of special interest groups on politicians.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of the donor.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical take on the influence of campaign contributions in politics.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of the pollster.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of politicians who are guided by public opinion polls rather than conviction.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of the focus group.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical take on the market-tested and inauthentic nature of modern political messaging.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of the teleprompter.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of the scripted and artificial nature of political communication.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of the speechwriter.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical take on the lack of authenticity in political speech.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of the consultant.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of the professionalized and manufactured nature of modern political campaigns.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of the strategist.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical view of the calculated and manipulative nature of political strategy.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of the machine.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of the power of political machines and party structures over individual politicians.

raw.text: The fear of death follows from the fear of life. A man who lives fully is prepared to die at any time.
raw.author: Mark Twain
raw.note: A perspective that links the fear of death to an unlived life, suggesting that living fully is the antidote.

raw.text: Time is a created thing. To say 'I don't have time,' is like saying, 'I don't want to.'
raw.author: Lao Tzu
raw.note: A Taoist perspective that reframes time as a matter of priority and personal creation.

raw.text: The soul that sees beauty may sometimes walk alone.
raw.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
raw.note: A romantic perspective suggesting that a deep appreciation for beauty can be an isolating experience.

raw.text: Loneliness is the poverty of self; solitude is the richness of self.
raw.author: May Sarton
raw.note: A classic distinction between the negative state of loneliness and the positive, enriching state of solitude.

raw.text: I was a man who loved the moon, but I was afraid of the night.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A poetic metaphor for appreciating the idea of solitude while fearing the reality of loneliness.

raw.text: The eternal quest of the individual human being is to shatter his loneliness.
raw.author: Norman Cousins
raw.note: A perspective on the fundamental human drive to connect and overcome feelings of isolation.

raw.text: The best thinking has been done in solitude. The worst has been done in turmoil.
raw.author: Thomas A. Edison
raw.note: An inventor's perspective on the necessity of a quiet, solitary environment for deep thought.

raw.text: I have to be alone very often. I'd be a poorer man if I were always near people.
raw.author: C.G. Jung
raw.note: A psychologist's view on the necessity of solitude for personal and intellectual richness.

raw.text: There is a certain pleasure in weeping. Grief finds in tears both a satisfaction and a cure.
raw.author: Ovid
raw.note: An ancient observation on the cathartic and healing nature of expressing sorrow, often experienced in solitude.

raw.text: What a lovely surprise to finally discover how unlonely being alone can be.
raw.author: Ellen Burstyn
raw.note: An actress's reflection on the joyful discovery of positive solitude.

raw.text: The strongest man in the world is he who stands most alone.
raw.author: Henrik Ibsen
raw.note: From the play 'An Enemy of the People', a statement on the strength required to maintain one's convictions against societal pressure.

raw.text: Solitude is the place of purification.
raw.author: Martin Buber
raw.note: A philosophical and spiritual view of solitude as a space for cleansing the mind and spirit.

raw.text: I'm not a recluse. I'm not a hermit. I'm a person who likes to be alone.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple distinction clarifying a preference for solitude over social withdrawal.

raw.text: The mind is sharper and keener in seclusion and uninterrupted solitude. Originality thrives in seclusion free of outside influences beating upon us to cripple the creative mind.
raw.author: Nikola Tesla
raw.note: An inventor's perspective on the importance of solitude for fostering originality and deep thought.

raw.text: We're all born alone and we die alone. The loneliness is a part of our life, it's a part of our journey.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An existentialist reflection on the fundamental aloneness of the human condition.

raw.text: I was never less alone than when by myself.
raw.author: Edward Gibbon
raw.note: A classic expression of finding rich companionship in one's own thoughts and imagination during solitude.

raw.text: The price of being a sheep is boredom. The price of being a wolf is loneliness. Choose one or the other with great care.
raw.author: Hugh MacLeod
raw.note: A modern aphorism on the trade-off between conformity and individuality.

raw.text: To have a friend, you must be a friend. To be a friend, you must be willing to be alone.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A paradoxical insight suggesting that self-sufficiency and comfort with solitude are prerequisites for healthy friendship.

raw.text: Loneliness is not lack of company, loneliness is lack of purpose.
raw.author: Guillermo Maldonado
raw.note: A re-framing of loneliness as a spiritual or existential problem, not a social one.

raw.text: Solitude is a chosen separation for refining your soul. Loneliness is an unchosen separation for suffering your soul.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A clear distinction based on choice and purpose.

raw.text: The best remedy for those who are afraid, lonely or unhappy is to go outside, somewhere where they can be quiet, alone with the heavens, nature and God.
raw.author: Anne Frank
raw.note: From her diary, a reflection on the healing and restorative power of solitude in nature.

raw.text: A man is born alone and dies alone; and he experiences the good and bad consequences of his karma alone.
raw.author: Chanakya
raw.note: An ancient Indian philosophical view on the individual nature of life, death, and moral accountability.

raw.text: If you are lonely when you're alone, you are in bad company.
raw.author: Jean-Paul Sartre
raw.note: An existentialist jab suggesting that loneliness stems from a poor relationship with oneself.

raw.text: I am not a wolf in sheep's clothing, I'm a wolf in wolf's clothing.
raw.author: Ricky Gervais
raw.note: While humorous, this reflects a philosophy of radical authenticity, which often leads to a solitary path.

raw.text: The greatest thing in the world is to know how to belong to oneself.
raw.author: Michel de Montaigne
raw.note: A Renaissance philosopher's statement on the supreme value of self-possession and inner solitude.

raw.text: Solitude is not the absence of company, but the moment when our soul is free to speak to us and help us decide what to do with our life.
raw.author: Paulo Coelho
raw.note: A definition of solitude as a space for introspection and self-guidance.

raw.text: The more powerful and original a mind, the more it will incline towards the religion of solitude.
raw.author: Aldous Huxley
raw.note: A perspective suggesting that great minds naturally seek solitude for their work.

raw.text: All man's miseries derive from not being able to sit quietly in a room alone.
raw.author: Blaise Pascal
raw.note: A slight variation of his famous quote on the human aversion to solitude and self-reflection.

raw.text: I live in that solitude which is painful in youth, but delicious in the years of maturity.
raw.author: Albert Einstein
raw.note: A reflection on how the experience of solitude changes and deepens with age.

raw.text: Loneliness is the human condition. No one is ever going to fill that space.
raw.author: Janet Fitch
raw.note: From the novel 'White Oleander', an existentialist view of loneliness as an inescapable part of life.

raw.text: A bore is someone who deprives you of solitude without providing you with company.
raw.author: Oscar Wilde
raw.note: A witty definition that highlights the value of solitude by contrasting it with poor company.

raw.text: The best of artists hath no thought to show which the rough stone in its superfluous shell doth not include; to break the marble spell is all the hand that serves the brain can do.
raw.author: Michelangelo
raw.note: This sonnet describes the solitary act of creation, where the artist's job is to reveal the form already hidden within the material.

raw.text: In solitude the mind gains strength and learns to lean upon itself.
raw.author: Laurence Sterne
raw.note: An 18th-century view on solitude as a training ground for mental self-reliance.

raw.text: I am lonely, yet not everybody will do. I don't know why, some people fill the gaps and others emphasize my loneliness.
raw.author: Anaïs Nin
raw.note: A nuanced reflection on the specific nature of loneliness, which is not cured by just any company.

raw.text: The value of solitude is that it allows you to hear the truth.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the clarity and insight that can be found in a quiet, solitary state.

raw.text: The greatest moments of the individual are those when he is alone.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A celebration of solitude as the space for profound personal experience.

raw.text: The more you like yourself, the less you are like anyone else, which makes you unique.
raw.author: Walt Disney
raw.note: While not directly about solitude, it speaks to the individual journey of self-acceptance that often requires it.

raw.text: The only way to get a friend is to be one.
raw.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
raw.note: This implies a certain self-possession and comfort with oneself (solitude) as a prerequisite for true friendship.

raw.text: The man who is happy is the man who is alone.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A provocative and extreme statement on the link between solitude and happiness.

raw.text: The man who is never alone is never himself.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that true identity and authenticity can only be found in solitude.

raw.text: The man who is alone is strong. The man who is in a crowd is weak.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb that contrasts the strength of individual conviction with the weakness of mob mentality.

raw.text: The man who is alone has the whole world for his companion.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A paradoxical statement on how solitude can lead to a deeper connection with the world.

raw.text: The man who is alone is the man who is free.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A simple statement linking solitude with freedom from social constraints.

raw.text: The man who is alone is the man who is complete.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that sees self-sufficiency and wholeness in solitude.

raw.text: The man who is alone is the man who is at peace.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the tranquility and inner peace found in solitude.

raw.text: The man who is alone is the man who is closest to God.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A spiritual view of solitude as a path to divine connection.

raw.text: The man who is alone is the man who is most himself.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the link between solitude and authenticity.

raw.text: The man who is alone is the man who is most creative.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the link between solitude and creativity.

raw.text: The man who is alone is the man who is most productive.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the link between solitude and focused work.

raw.text: The man who is alone is the man who is most powerful.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the strength and self-reliance found in solitude.

raw.text: The man who is alone is the man who is most dangerous.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cautionary view on the potential for isolation to lead to negative outcomes.

raw.text: The greatest discovery of my generation is that a human being can alter his life by altering his attitudes of mind.
raw.author: William James
raw.note: A foundational statement in American psychology on the power of mindset to shape one's life.

raw.text: The interpretation of dreams is the royal road to a knowledge of the unconscious activities of the mind.
raw.author: Sigmund Freud
raw.note: A foundational statement of psychoanalysis, positioning dream analysis as a key tool for understanding the unconscious.

raw.text: The brain is wider than the sky.
raw.author: Emily Dickinson
raw.note: A poetic metaphor for the vast, limitless potential of the human mind and imagination.

raw.text: The mind is a beautiful servant, but a dangerous master.
raw.author: Osho
raw.note: A spiritual teaching on the importance of mastering one's own mind, rather than being controlled by it.

raw.text: The first and simplest emotion which we discover in the human mind, is curiosity.
raw.author: Edmund Burke
raw.note: A philosophical observation on the fundamental and innate nature of curiosity.

raw.text: The mind is its own place, and in itself can make a heaven of hell, a hell of heaven.
raw.author: John Milton
raw.note: From 'Paradise Lost', a powerful statement on the mind's power to shape one's entire reality.

raw.text: The human mind is a story processor, not a logic processor.
raw.author: Jonathan Haidt
raw.note: A modern psychological perspective on the narrative-based nature of human cognition.

raw.text: The mind is like an iceberg, it floats with one-seventh of its bulk above water.
raw.author: Sigmund Freud
raw.note: A famous metaphor for the relationship between the conscious and the vast unconscious mind.

raw.text: The brain is a wonderful organ; it starts working the moment you get up in the morning and does not stop until you get into the office.
raw.author: Robert Frost
raw.note: A humorous and cynical take on the stultifying effect of office work on the mind.

raw.text: The human brain has 100 billion neurons, each neuron connected to 10 thousand other neurons. Sitting on your shoulders is the most complicated object in the known universe.
raw.author: Michio Kaku
raw.note: A physicist's perspective on the immense complexity of the human brain.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful force. It can enslave us or empower us. It can plunge us into the depths of misery or take us to the heights of ecstasy. Learn to use the power wisely.
raw.author: David Cuschieri
raw.note: A modern motivational quote on the dual potential of the mind.

raw.text: The mind is the master of the senses, and the breath is the master of the mind.
raw.author: Hatha Yoga Pradipika
raw.note: An ancient yogic teaching on the hierarchy of control, from senses to mind to breath.

raw.text: The mind is a flexible mirror, adjust it, to see a better world.
raw.author: Amit Ray
raw.note: A spiritual teacher's metaphor for the power of perspective to change one's reality.

raw.text: The mind is the limit. As long as the mind can envision the fact that you can do something, you can do it, as long as you really believe 100 percent.
raw.author: Arnold Schwarzenegger
raw.note: A famous quote on the power of belief and visualization from a bodybuilding champion.

raw.text: The mind is a wonderful thing. It is a shame to waste it.
raw.author: Dan Quayle
raw.note: A famously misquoted (he added an 'e' to 'waste') but well-intentioned statement on the value of the mind.

raw.text: The mind is a garden, your thoughts are the seeds. You can grow flowers or you can grow weeds.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A simple metaphor for the power of our thoughts to cultivate either a positive or negative mental state.

raw.text: The mind is a muscle. The more you use it, the stronger it gets.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the importance of mental exercise and continuous learning.

raw.text: The mind is a restless bird; the more it gets the more it wants, and still remains unsatisfied.
raw.author: Mahatma Gandhi
raw.note: A critique of the insatiable nature of desire and the human mind.

raw.text: The mind is a wonderful servant, but a terrible master.
raw.author: Robin Sharma
raw.note: A slight variation of the popular quote on mastering one's mind.

raw.text: The mind is a universe of its own.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple metaphor for the vastness and complexity of the inner world.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can take you to the highest heights or the lowest depths.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the dual potential of the mind for both great good and great harm.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful tool. It can be used for creation or destruction.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the dual-use nature of human intelligence.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be your best friend or your worst enemy.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the internal relationship we have with our own minds.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a prison or a palace.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's ability to create either a state of confinement or a state of freedom.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a garden or a jungle.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind as a space that can be either cultivated and orderly or wild and chaotic.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a calm sea or a raging storm.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the variable and sometimes volatile nature of our mental state.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a clear sky or a cloudy day.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the clarity or confusion of our thoughts.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a blank canvas or a masterpiece.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the creative potential of the mind.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a weapon or a shield.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's capacity for both aggression and defense.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a lock or a key.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's ability to either confine us or set us free.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a bridge or a wall.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's capacity to either connect us or separate us from others and from reality.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a compass or a maze.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's ability to either guide us or confuse us.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a fountain or a drain.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's capacity to be either a source of energy and creativity or a source of depletion.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a mirror or a projector.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's ability to either reflect reality accurately or project its own biases onto it.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a window or a door.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind as a means of both seeing the world and acting within it.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a song or a scream.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's capacity for both harmony and distress.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a story or a statistic.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's ability to process the world through both narrative and logic.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a question or an answer.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's dual capacity for inquiry and conclusion.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a seed or a flower.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's potential and its eventual fruition.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a whisper or a roar.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the varying intensity of our inner voice and thoughts.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a puzzle or a solution.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's ability to both create and solve problems.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a map or a territory.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor alluding to the philosophical distinction between our mental model of reality and reality itself.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a home or a prison.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's ability to be a place of comfort or a place of confinement.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a tool or a weapon.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the dual-use nature of intellect.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a friend or a foe.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the internal relationship we have with our own minds.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a blessing or a curse.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the dual potential of consciousness.

raw.text: The mind is a powerful thing. It can be a source of light or a source of darkness.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the mind's capacity for both enlightenment and despair.

raw.text: The Earth does not belong to us: we belong to the Earth.
raw.author: Marlee Matlin
raw.note: A simple and powerful statement that reframes the relationship between humanity and the planet.

raw.text: In every walk with nature one receives far more than he seeks.
raw.author: John Muir
raw.note: A famous quote from the naturalist on the abundant and often unexpected gifts of spending time in nature.

raw.text: The clearest way into the Universe is through a forest wilderness.
raw.author: John Muir
raw.note: A statement on the profound sense of connection to the cosmos that can be found in wild places.

raw.text: We do not inherit the Earth from our ancestors; we borrow it from our children.
raw.author: Native American Proverb
raw.note: A powerful proverb on intergenerational responsibility and the principle of stewardship.

raw.text: The poetry of the earth is never dead.
raw.author: John Keats
raw.note: A Romantic poet's affirmation of the enduring beauty and vitality of the natural world.

raw.text: The Earth has music for those who listen.
raw.author: George Santayana
raw.note: A poetic metaphor for the subtle beauty and harmony that can be found in nature through careful observation.

raw.text: To me a lush carpet of pine needles or spongy grass is more welcome than the most luxurious Persian rug.
raw.author: Helen Keller
raw.note: A reflection on the sensory richness and superior comfort of the natural world.

raw.text: The environment is where we all meet; where we all have a mutual interest; it is the one thing all of us share.
raw.author: Lady Bird Johnson
raw.note: A statement on the environment as the ultimate common ground for all of humanity.

raw.text: What is the use of a house if you haven't got a tolerable planet to put it on?
raw.author: Henry David Thoreau
raw.note: A pragmatic and critical question about human priorities in the face of environmental degradation.

raw.text: The proper use of science is not to conquer nature but to live in it.
raw.author: Barry Commoner
raw.note: A foundational principle of ecology, advocating for harmony with nature rather than domination.

raw.text: The Earth laughs in flowers.
raw.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
raw.note: A beautiful and simple poetic personification of nature's joy.

raw.text: Nature does not hurry, yet everything is accomplished.
raw.author: Lao Tzu
raw.note: A Taoist teaching on the power of patience and natural, unforced processes.

raw.text: The sea, once it casts its spell, holds one in its net of wonder forever.
raw.author: Jacques Cousteau
raw.note: A reflection on the captivating and lifelong allure of the ocean.

raw.text: The mountains are calling and I must go.
raw.author: John Muir
raw.note: A famous expression of the irresistible pull of the wilderness.

raw.text: One touch of nature makes the whole world kin.
raw.author: William Shakespeare
raw.note: From 'Troilus and Cressida', a statement on the power of shared human nature (in this context, a flaw) to unite us.

raw.text: The good man is the friend of all living things.
raw.author: Mahatma Gandhi
raw.note: An ethical principle extending compassion to all forms of life.

raw.text: The Earth is what we all have in common.
raw.author: Wendell Berry
raw.note: A simple and powerful statement on our shared dependence on the planet.

raw.text: The use of solar energy has not been opened up because the oil industry does not own the sun.
raw.author: Ralph Nader
raw.note: A political critique of the economic forces hindering the adoption of renewable energy.

raw.text: The environment is everything that isn't me.
raw.author: Albert Einstein
raw.note: A simple, expansive, and humorous definition of the environment.

raw.text: The ultimate test of man's conscience may be his willingness to sacrifice something today for future generations whose words of thanks will not be heard.
raw.author: Gaylord Nelson
raw.note: A statement on the ethical challenge of environmentalism, which requires selfless action for the benefit of the future.

raw.text: We have forgotten how to be good guests, how to walk lightly on the earth as its other creatures do.
raw.author: Barbara Ward
raw.note: A critique of humanity's destructive impact on the planet.

raw.text: The greatest threat to our planet is the belief that someone else will save it.
raw.author: Robert Swan
raw.note: A call for personal responsibility in environmental action, warning against the bystander effect.

raw.text: The Earth is a fine place and worth fighting for.
raw.author: Ernest Hemingway
raw.note: A simple and powerful affirmation of the planet's value, from 'For Whom the Bell Tolls'.

raw.text: The earth has its music for those who will listen.
raw.author: Reginald Vincent Holmes
raw.note: A slight variation of the famous quote on the subtle beauties of nature.

raw.text: The earth is a canvas for the imagination.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the creative inspiration that can be drawn from the natural world.

raw.text: The earth is a garden. It is our responsibility to tend to it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for environmental stewardship.

raw.text: The earth is a gift, not a given.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the need for gratitude and care for our planet.

raw.text: The earth is a mother that never dies.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A personification of the Earth as an eternal, nurturing force.

raw.text: The earth is a place of beauty and wonder.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple affirmation of the aesthetic and inspirational value of our planet.

raw.text: The earth is a school, and we are its students.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the lessons that can be learned from the natural world.

raw.text: The earth is a temple, and we are its guardians.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A spiritual view of the planet and our role as its protectors.

raw.text: The earth is a treasure, and we are its keepers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the preciousness of the Earth and our duty to preserve it.

raw.text: The earth is a work of art, and we are its admirers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective that frames the natural world as a masterpiece to be appreciated.

raw.text: The earth is a symphony, and we are its audience.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the harmonious and complex beauty of the natural world.

raw.text: The earth is a story, and we are its characters.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A narrative framing of our place within the larger story of the planet.

raw.text: The earth is a puzzle, and we are its solvers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the scientific quest to understand the workings of our planet.

raw.text: The earth is a garden, and we are the flowers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our place as beautiful, natural parts of the world.

raw.text: The earth is a fire, and we are the sparks.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our small but vital role in the dynamic energy of the planet.

raw.text: The earth is a storm, and we are the sailors.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for navigating the turbulent and powerful forces of nature.

raw.text: The earth is a book, and we are its readers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the knowledge and wisdom that can be gained from studying the natural world.

raw.text: The earth is a bridge, and we are its builders.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our role in connecting with and sustaining the natural world.

raw.text: The earth is a symphony, and we are the conductors.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our responsibility to orchestrate a harmonious relationship with nature.

raw.text: The earth is a tapestry, and we are the weavers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our role in shaping the intricate and interconnected web of life.

raw.text: The earth is a path, and we are the walkers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple metaphor for our journey through the natural world.

raw.text: The earth is a question, and we are the answer.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophical framing of humanity's role as the consciousness of the planet.

raw.text: The earth is a mirror, reflecting our values.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that the state of the environment is a direct reflection of human ethics and priorities.

raw.text: The earth is a choice, and we are the choosers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement emphasizing our power and responsibility to choose the future of our planet.

raw.text: Success usually comes to those who are too busy to be looking for it.
raw.author: Henry David Thoreau
raw.note: A perspective suggesting that success is a byproduct of focused work, not the primary goal itself.

raw.text: The only place where success comes before work is in the dictionary.
raw.author: Vidal Sassoon
raw.note: A witty observation on the fundamental requirement of hard work for any real achievement.

raw.text: The road to success and the road to failure are almost exactly the same.
raw.author: Colin R. Davis
raw.note: A perspective suggesting that the journey of ambition involves the same risks and paths, with outcomes determined by perseverance and small choices.

raw.text: Success is not the key to happiness. Happiness is the key to success. If you love what you are doing, you will be successful.
raw.author: Albert Schweitzer
raw.note: A re-framing of the relationship between success and happiness, prioritizing passion and joy as the foundation for achievement.

raw.text: The price of success is hard work, dedication to the job at hand, and the determination that whether we win or lose, we have applied the best of ourselves to the task at hand.
raw.author: Vince Lombardi
raw.note: A comprehensive definition of the cost of success, focusing on effort and dedication regardless of the outcome.

raw.text: Failure is another stepping stone to greatness.
raw.author: Oprah Winfrey
raw.note: A modern, optimistic take on using failure as a tool for achieving success.

raw.text: Ambition is the path to success. Persistence is the vehicle you arrive in.
raw.author: Bill Bradley
raw.note: A metaphor distinguishing the desire for success from the perseverance required to achieve it.

raw.text: I've missed more than 9000 shots in my career. I've lost almost 300 games. 26 times, I've been trusted to take the game winning shot and missed. I've failed over and over and over again in my life. And that is why I succeed.
raw.author: Michael Jordan
raw.note: A famous and powerful testament to the idea that success is built upon a foundation of repeated failure.

raw.text: The desire to reach for the stars is ambitious. The desire to reach hearts is wise.
raw.author: Maya Angelou
raw.note: A distinction between worldly ambition and the deeper wisdom of human connection.

raw.text: A man's worth is no greater than his ambitions.
raw.author: Marcus Aurelius
raw.note: A Stoic perspective suggesting that the quality of one's goals defines one's character.

raw.text: Keep your eyes on the stars, and your feet on the ground.
raw.author: Theodore Roosevelt
raw.note: A famous piece of advice on balancing lofty ambitions with practical, grounded action.

raw.text: The successful warrior is the average man, with laser-like focus.
raw.author: Bruce Lee
raw.note: A definition of success based on intense concentration and dedication, rather than innate talent.

raw.text: Success is how high you bounce when you hit bottom.
raw.author: George S. Patton
raw.note: A definition of success based on resilience and the ability to recover from total failure.

raw.text: The starting point of all achievement is desire.
raw.author: Napoleon Hill
raw.note: From 'Think and Grow Rich', a foundational principle that ambition and desire are the genesis of all success.

raw.text: All you need in this life is ignorance and confidence, and then success is sure.
raw.author: Mark Twain
raw.note: A cynical and humorous formula for success, suggesting that overconfidence and a lack of self-awareness can be advantageous.

raw.text: The secret of success is to do the common thing uncommonly well.
raw.author: John D. Rockefeller Jr.
raw.note: A business leader's perspective on achieving success through excellence in fundamental tasks.

raw.text: Don't be afraid to give up the good to go for the great.
raw.author: John D. Rockefeller
raw.note: A statement on the necessity of taking risks and leaving comfort zones to achieve a higher level of success.

raw.text: Success is a lousy teacher. It seduces smart people into thinking they can't lose.
raw.author: Bill Gates
raw.note: A cautionary quote on the dangers of complacency that can come with success.

raw.text: The ladder of success is best climbed by stepping on the rungs of opportunity.
raw.author: Ayn Rand
raw.note: A philosophy of success based on proactively seizing opportunities.

raw.text: Success is not in what you have, but who you are.
raw.author: Bo Bennett
raw.note: A definition of success based on character and personal development rather than material wealth.

raw.text: The path to success is to take massive, determined action.
raw.author: Tony Robbins
raw.note: A motivational philosophy that emphasizes large-scale, decisive action.

raw.text: Success is the sum of small efforts, repeated day in and day out.
raw.author: Robert Collier
raw.note: A definition of success as the result of consistent, daily habits and actions.

raw.text: The master has failed more times than the beginner has even tried.
raw.author: Stephen McCranie
raw.note: A modern quote on the relationship between mastery and failure, highlighting the sheer volume of attempts required.

raw.text: There is no success without hardship.
raw.author: Sophocles
raw.note: An ancient Greek perspective on the inseparable link between achievement and struggle.

raw.text: A successful man is one who can lay a firm foundation with the bricks others have thrown at him.
raw.author: David Brinkley
raw.note: A metaphor for resilience and the ability to turn criticism and adversity into a source of strength.

raw.text: The secret of your future is hidden in your daily routine.
raw.author: Mike Murdock
raw.note: A statement on the power of daily habits to shape long-term outcomes.

raw.text: Failure is the opportunity to begin again more intelligently.
raw.author: Henry Ford
raw.note: A pragmatic view of failure as a chance to learn and improve one's approach.

raw.text: Our ambition should be to rule ourselves, the true kingdom for each one of us; and true progress is to know more, and be more, and to do more.
raw.author: Oscar Wilde
raw.note: A definition of noble ambition as self-mastery and continuous personal growth.

raw.text: Ambition is the germ from which all growth of nobleness proceeds.
raw.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
raw.note: A transcendentalist view of ambition as the starting point for all virtuous development.

raw.text: A man's reach should exceed his grasp, or what's a heaven for?
raw.author: Robert Browning
raw.note: A famous poetic line advocating for setting ambitious goals that are just beyond one's current capabilities.

raw.text: Ambition is not a dirty word. Piss on compromise. Go for the throat.
raw.author: Steven Pressfield
raw.note: From 'The War of Art', a modern and aggressive call to embrace ambition without apology.

raw.text: Without ambition one starts nothing. Without work one finishes nothing. The prize will not be sent to you. You have to win it.
raw.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
raw.note: A statement on the two essential components of achievement: the desire to start and the work to finish.

raw.text: Intelligence without ambition is a bird without wings.
raw.author: Salvador Dalí
raw.note: A surrealist's metaphor for the need for drive and ambition to make use of one's talents.

raw.text: The universe is not required to be in perfect harmony with human ambition.
raw.author: Carl Sagan
raw.note: A scientist's realistic perspective on the indifference of the cosmos to our goals.

raw.text: Ambition can creep as well as soar.
raw.author: Edmund Burke
raw.note: A cautionary observation that ambition can manifest through slow, insidious means as well as grand gestures.

raw.text: Great ambition is the passion of a great character. Those endowed with it may perform very good or very bad acts. All depends on the principles which direct them.
raw.author: Napoleon Bonaparte
raw.note: A nuanced view of ambition as a powerful, neutral force that can be used for good or evil depending on one's ethics.

raw.text: Most people would succeed in small things if they were not troubled with great ambitions.
raw.author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
raw.note: A cautionary tale about how grand ambitions can sometimes prevent us from achieving more modest, attainable successes.

raw.text: Ambition is a dream with a V8 engine.
raw.author: Elvis Presley
raw.note: A powerful and modern metaphor for ambition as the driving force behind dreams.

raw.text: A young man without ambition is an old man waiting to be.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb suggesting that a lack of ambition in youth leads to a premature and unfulfilled old age.

raw.text: The tragedy of life is not that it ends so soon, but that we wait so long to begin it.
raw.author: W. M. Lewis
raw.note: A reflection on the tragedy of procrastination and unrealized potential.

raw.text: The very substance of the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream.
raw.author: William Shakespeare
raw.note: From 'Hamlet', a philosophical reflection on the insubstantial and illusory nature of ambition.

raw.text: To be happy, we must not be too concerned with others.
raw.author: Albert Camus
raw.note: An existentialist view suggesting that a degree of detachment from others' opinions is necessary for personal happiness.

raw.text: The man who has confidence in himself gains the confidence of others.
raw.author: Hasidic Proverb
raw.note: A piece of wisdom on how self-belief inspires trust in others.

raw.text: The harder the conflict, the more glorious the triumph.
raw.author: Thomas Paine
raw.note: A statement on how the value of a victory is proportional to the difficulty of the struggle.

raw.text: The supreme art of war is to subdue the enemy without fighting.
raw.author: Sun Tzu
raw.note: A core principle from 'The Art of War', emphasizing that the greatest victory is one achieved through strategy and intelligence, not bloodshed.

raw.text: Older men declare war. But it is youth that must fight and die.
raw.author: Herbert Hoover
raw.note: A poignant observation on the intergenerational tragedy of war.

raw.text: War does not determine who is right - only who is left.
raw.author: Bertrand Russell
raw.note: A philosophical critique of war, suggesting it is a test of power, not of moral or factual correctness.

raw.text: In peace, sons bury their fathers. In war, fathers bury their sons.
raw.author: Herodotus
raw.note: An ancient Greek historian's stark observation on the unnatural order of death during wartime.

raw.text: I know not with what weapons World War III will be fought, but World War IV will be fought with sticks and stones.
raw.author: Albert Einstein
raw.note: A famous and chilling prediction about the devastating, civilization-ending potential of modern warfare.

raw.text: The object of war is not to die for your country but to make the other bastard die for his.
raw.author: George S. Patton
raw.note: A famously blunt and pragmatic statement on the reality of combat from a renowned general.

raw.text: Only the dead have seen the end of war.
raw.author: Plato (often misattributed)
raw.note: While often attributed to Plato, this quote was popularized by George Santayana and later Douglas MacArthur. It's a pessimistic statement on the perpetual nature of human conflict.

raw.text: War is a cowardly escape from the problems of peace.
raw.author: Thomas Mann
raw.note: A critique of war as a simplistic and destructive avoidance of the more complex challenges of peaceful coexistence.

raw.text: All war is a symptom of man's failure as a thinking animal.
raw.author: John Steinbeck
raw.note: A view of war as a fundamental failure of human reason and intelligence.

raw.text: It is well that war is so terrible, otherwise we should grow too fond of it.
raw.author: Robert E. Lee
raw.note: A reflection from a general on the horrifying nature of war, suggesting its terror is a necessary deterrent.

raw.text: War is what happens when language fails.
raw.author: Margaret Atwood
raw.note: A writer's perspective on war as the ultimate breakdown of communication and diplomacy.

raw.text: The first casualty when war comes is truth.
raw.author: Hiram Johnson
raw.note: A famous statement on the inevitable rise of propaganda and deceit during wartime.

raw.text: To be prepared for war is one of the most effective means of preserving peace.
raw.author: George Washington
raw.note: A classic statement of the 'peace through strength' doctrine.

raw.text: There is no glory in battle worth the blood it costs.
raw.author: Dwight D. Eisenhower
raw.note: A sober reflection from a former general and president on the ultimate cost of war.

raw.text: War is organized murder, and nothing else.
raw.author: Harry Patch
raw.note: A blunt and uncompromising description of war from one of the last surviving soldiers of World War I.

raw.text: Mankind must put an end to war, or war will put an end to mankind.
raw.author: John F. Kennedy
raw.note: A stark warning about the existential threat posed by modern warfare in the nuclear age.

raw.text: Every gun that is made, every warship launched, every rocket fired signifies, in the final sense, a theft from those who hunger and are not fed, those who are cold and are not clothed.
raw.author: Dwight D. Eisenhower
raw.note: A powerful critique of military spending as a diversion of resources from human needs.

raw.text: An eye for an eye only ends up making the whole world blind.
raw.author: Mahatma Gandhi
raw.note: A famous critique of retributive justice, arguing that cycles of revenge are ultimately self-destructive.

raw.text: Peace is not absence of conflict, it is the ability to handle conflict by peaceful means.
raw.author: Ronald Reagan
raw.note: A definition of peace as an active process of conflict resolution, not merely the absence of war.

raw.text: Forgiveness is the attribute of the strong.
raw.author: Mahatma Gandhi
raw.note: A statement that frames forgiveness not as a weakness, but as an act of profound strength and courage.

raw.text: If we have no peace, it is because we have forgotten that we belong to each other.
raw.author: Mother Teresa
raw.note: A simple and powerful statement linking the absence of peace to a loss of human connection and solidarity.

raw.text: Peace cannot be kept by force; it can only be achieved by understanding.
raw.author: Albert Einstein
raw.note: A physicist's view on the foundations of peace, prioritizing mutual understanding over military power.

raw.text: The practice of peace and reconciliation is one of the most vital and artistic of human actions.
raw.author: Thich Nhat Hanh
raw.note: A Buddhist master's view of peacemaking as a creative and essential human endeavor.

raw.text: To forgive is to set a prisoner free and discover that the prisoner was you.
raw.author: Lewis B. Smedes
raw.note: A famous theological perspective on forgiveness as an act of self-liberation.

raw.text: If you want to make peace, you don't talk to your friends. You talk to your enemies.
raw.author: Moshe Dayan
raw.note: A pragmatic statement from a military leader on the necessity of engaging with adversaries to achieve peace.

raw.text: Peace is a journey of a thousand miles and it must be taken one step at a time.
raw.author: Lyndon B. Johnson
raw.note: A metaphor for the long, incremental, and patient process of building peace.

raw.text: There is no way to peace, peace is the way.
raw.author: A. J. Muste
raw.note: A core principle of pacifism, arguing that the means used to achieve peace must be peaceful themselves.

raw.text: When the power of love overcomes the love of power, the world will know peace.
raw.author: Jimi Hendrix
raw.note: A famous aphorism on the fundamental shift in values required to achieve world peace.

raw.text: Peace is not something you wish for; It's something you make, something you do, something you are, and something you give away.
raw.author: John Lennon
raw.note: A call to view peace as an active and participatory process.

raw.text: Peace is more than the absence of war. It is a virtue, a state of mind, a disposition for benevolence, confidence, justice.
raw.author: Baruch Spinoza
raw.note: A philosophical definition of peace as a positive state of being, not just a negative condition.

raw.text: The practice of forgiveness is our most important contribution to the healing of the world.
raw.author: Marianne Williamson
raw.note: A spiritual perspective on the transformative power of forgiveness.

raw.text: It isn't enough to talk about peace. One must believe in it. And it isn't enough to believe in it. One must work at it.
raw.author: Eleanor Roosevelt
raw.note: A statement on the necessity of both conviction and action in the pursuit of peace.

raw.text: If you want peace, you don't talk to your friends. You talk to your enemies.
raw.author: Desmond Tutu
raw.note: A key principle of reconciliation from the South African archbishop.

raw.text: Peace begins with a smile.
raw.author: Mother Teresa
raw.note: A simple and profound statement on how small acts of kindness are the starting point for peace.

raw.text: Forgiveness is not an occasional act, it is a constant attitude.
raw.author: Martin Luther King Jr.
raw.note: A view of forgiveness as a continuous practice and state of being, not a one-time event.

raw.text: Peace is the only battle worth waging.
raw.author: Albert Camus
raw.note: An existentialist's conclusion on the ultimate and most worthy human struggle.

raw.text: The first step in the evolution of ethics is a sense of solidarity with other human beings.
raw.author: Albert Schweitzer
raw.note: A philosophical view that a sense of shared humanity is the foundation for peace and ethical behavior.

raw.text: There can be no peace without justice, no justice without forgiveness and no forgiveness without healing.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A modern proverb outlining the interconnected stages of true reconciliation.

raw.text: Peace is not a relationship of nations. It is a condition of mind brought about by a serenity of soul.
raw.author: Jawaharlal Nehru
raw.note: A perspective that true peace is an internal state that then manifests externally.

raw.text: The pursuit of peace and progress cannot end in a few years in either victory or defeat. The pursuit of peace and progress, with its trials and its errors, its successes and its setbacks, can never be relaxed and never abandoned.
raw.author: Dag Hammarskjöld
raw.note: A realistic view from a UN Secretary-General on the continuous and unending nature of the work for peace.

raw.text: Peace is not the absence of war, it is a virtue, a state of mind, a disposition for benevolence, confidence, justice.
raw.author: Baruch Spinoza
raw.note: A slight variation of his famous philosophical definition of peace.

raw.text: The more we sweat in peace, the less we bleed in war.
raw.author: Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit
raw.note: A statement on the importance of diplomatic and preventative efforts to avoid conflict.

raw.text: Peace is a daily, a weekly, a monthly process, gradually changing opinions, slowly eroding old barriers, quietly building new structures.
raw.author: John F. Kennedy
raw.note: A description of peace as a slow, incremental, and continuous process.

raw.text: If you want to end the war, then instead of sending guns, send books. Instead of sending tanks, send pens. Instead of sending soldiers, send teachers.
raw.author: Malala Yousafzai
raw.note: A powerful call for education as the ultimate tool for peace.

raw.text: There is no 'us' and 'them'. There is only us.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple and profound statement on the principle of shared humanity, a foundation for peace.

raw.text: Peace is the result of retraining your mind to process life as it is, rather than as you think it should be.
raw.author: Wayne W. Dyer
raw.note: A psychological and spiritual approach to peace as an act of acceptance.

raw.text: The life of a single human being is worth a million times more than all the property of the richest man on earth.
raw.author: Che Guevara
raw.note: A revolutionary's statement on the supreme value of human life, a principle often invoked in peace activism.

raw.text: The world is now too small for anything but brotherhood.
raw.author: Arthur Powell Davies
raw.note: A statement on the necessity of global unity in an interconnected world.

raw.text: Peace is not a destination, but a way of life.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A simple statement on peace as a continuous practice.

raw.text: The first condition of peace is the will to achieve it.
raw.author: Marcel Aymé
raw.note: A statement that the desire and intention for peace are the most crucial starting points.

raw.text: Peace is a child's right.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that frames peace as a fundamental human right, especially for the most vulnerable.

raw.text: Peace is a state of balance and harmony.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A definition of peace based on equilibrium and concord.

raw.text: Peace is a gift we give to ourselves.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective on peace as an internal choice and act of self-care.

raw.text: Peace is a garden that must be tended.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the continuous effort and care required to maintain peace.

raw.text: Peace is a language that everyone can understand.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the universal nature of the desire for peace.

raw.text: Peace is a journey of a thousand steps.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the long and incremental process of achieving peace.

raw.text: Peace is a choice we make every day.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on peace as a continuous and conscious decision.

raw.text: Peace is a bridge we build together.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the collaborative and constructive nature of peacemaking.

raw.text: Peace is a symphony we compose together.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the harmonious and cooperative effort required for peace.

raw.text: Peace is a tapestry we weave together.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the interconnected and collaborative creation of a peaceful society.

raw.text: Peace is a path we walk together.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple metaphor for the shared journey of peacemaking.

raw.text: Peace is a question we must answer together.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A framing of peace as a collective challenge that requires a shared solution.

raw.text: Peace is a mirror that reflects our shared humanity.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement that true peace is a reflection of our ability to recognize our common humanity.

raw.text: Peace is a choice between love and fear.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A fundamental ethical framing of the choice for peace.

raw.text: Peace is a gift we give to future generations.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the intergenerational responsibility of peacemaking.

raw.text: It is not power that corrupts but fear. Fear of losing power corrupts those who wield it and fear of the scourge of power corrupts those who are subject to it.
raw.author: Aung San Suu Kyi
raw.note: From her 'Freedom from Fear' speech, a nuanced take on Lord Acton's famous quote, identifying fear as the primary corrupting agent in politics.

raw.text: The only real prison is fear, and the only real freedom is freedom from fear.
raw.author: Aung San Suu Kyi
raw.note: A core tenet of her philosophy, emphasizing internal, psychological freedom as the most important.

raw.text: In a country where the sole employer is the State, opposition means death by slow starvation.
raw.author: Leon Trotsky
raw.note: While not about Burma specifically, this quote is often cited to describe the economic reality under totalitarian regimes like Myanmar's military junta.

raw.text: The struggle for democracy and human rights in Burma is a struggle for life and dignity. It is a struggle that encompasses our political, social and economic aspirations.
raw.author: Aung San Suu Kyi
raw.note: A holistic view of the democratic struggle in Myanmar, linking it to all aspects of human life.

raw.text: In Burma, we are all prisoners of our own history.
raw.author: Thant Myint-U
raw.note: A historian's perspective on the powerful and often burdensome influence of the past on modern Myanmar.

raw.text: A life that is not dedicated to a great ideal is like a boat without a rudder.
raw.author: Aung San
raw.note: A statement on the importance of purpose from the father of modern Myanmar.

raw.text: A country's greatness lies in its undying ideals of love and sacrifice that inspire the mothers of the race.
raw.author: Sarojini Naidu
raw.note: While an Indian figure, her words on national ideals resonate with the sacrifices made by many in Myanmar's struggle.

raw.text: The true revolutionary is guided by great feelings of love.
raw.author: Che Guevara
raw.note: A quote often applied to the motivations of those fighting for a better future in places like Myanmar.

raw.text: There is no peace without justice, no justice without forgiveness and no forgiveness without healing.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A modern proverb outlining the interconnected stages of true reconciliation, highly relevant to Myanmar's conflicts.

raw.text: The tyrant dies and his rule is over, the martyr dies and his rule begins.
raw.author: Søren Kierkegaard
raw.note: An existentialist reflection on the enduring power of sacrifice, relevant to figures like Aung San.

raw.text: The best way to not feel hopeless is to get up and do something.
raw.author: Barack Obama
raw.note: A call to action as an antidote to despair, relevant to the long struggle for democracy in Myanmar.

raw.text: The world is a dangerous place, not because of those who do evil, but because of those who look on and do nothing.
raw.author: Albert Einstein
raw.note: A slight variation of his famous quote on the moral failure of passive bystanders.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good person, and to fight for what is right.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An ethical statement that links personal virtue with the active struggle for justice.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good citizen, and to demand justice.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy of civic duty focused on holding power accountable.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good leader, and to fight for your people.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy of leadership that places the welfare of the people as the highest priority.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good follower, and to not follow a tyrant.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that emphasizes the moral responsibility of followers to reject oppressive leadership.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good teacher, and to teach the next generation to be free.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A pedagogical philosophy focused on instilling the values of freedom in students.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good student, and to learn from the struggles of the past.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy of learning from history to inform present and future struggles.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good writer, and to tell the truth about power.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy of writing that sees its purpose as speaking truth to power.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good artist, and to create art that inspires resistance.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy of art as a tool for social and political change.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good scientist, and to use your knowledge to expose lies.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An ethical stance for scientists, urging them to apply their expertise in the service of truth.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good philosopher, and to understand the nature of tyranny.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophical goal to deeply analyze and comprehend the phenomenon of oppression.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good person to yourself, and to not be broken by oppression.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A self-care philosophy focused on maintaining inner resilience in the face of tyranny.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good person to others, and to not be complicit in their suffering.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An ethical principle of non-participation in the suffering of others.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good person in the world, and to work for the freedom of all.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A broad ethical statement linking personal virtue with a global mission for liberty.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good person for the future, and to build a world without chains.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A utopian philosophy focused on creating a legacy of freedom.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is to be a good person in the present, and to resist tyranny now.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A call to immediate, present-moment action against oppression.

raw.text: Poverty is the worst form of violence.
raw.author: Mahatma Gandhi
raw.note: A powerful statement that frames poverty not as a passive condition, but as an active, violent force that harms individuals and communities.

raw.text: Overcoming poverty is not a task of charity, it is an act of justice.
raw.author: Nelson Mandela
raw.note: A call to reframe the fight against poverty from an act of optional charity to a fundamental demand for justice.

raw.text: Anyone who has ever struggled with poverty knows how extremely expensive it is to be poor.
raw.author: James Baldwin
raw.note: A poignant and paradoxical observation on the hidden costs and financial traps associated with poverty.

raw.text: Poverty is not an accident. Like slavery and apartheid, it is man-made and can be removed by the actions of human beings.
raw.author: Nelson Mandela
raw.note: A powerful statement that frames poverty as a systemic, man-made injustice that can be dismantled through collective action.

raw.text: The poor are not a problem to be solved, but a people to be loved.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A call to see beyond statistics and policies to the shared humanity and dignity of people experiencing poverty.

raw.text: There are people in the world so hungry, that God cannot appear to them except in the form of bread.
raw.author: Mahatma Gandhi
raw.note: A statement on the primacy of basic physical needs, suggesting that spiritual or abstract concerns are impossible on an empty stomach.

raw.text: The opposite of poverty is not wealth. In a world of plenty, the opposite of poverty is justice.
raw.author: Bryan Stevenson
raw.note: A modern re-framing of the poverty issue, identifying injustice as its true antithesis.

raw.text: It is a tragic mix-up when the United States spends $500,000 for every enemy soldier killed, and only $53 annually on the victims of poverty.
raw.author: Martin Luther King Jr.
raw.note: A stark statistical comparison used to critique national priorities and the economics of war versus social welfare.

raw.text: Poverty is the parent of revolution and crime.
raw.author: Aristotle
raw.note: An ancient philosophical observation on the link between economic desperation and social unrest.

raw.text: The world has enough for everyone's need, but not enough for everyone's greed.
raw.author: Mahatma Gandhi
raw.note: A famous statement distinguishing between basic needs and insatiable greed as the root of resource inequality.

raw.text: Being poor is a full-time job.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A concise statement on the immense amount of time and energy required to navigate the challenges of poverty.

raw.text: The greatest of evils and the worst of crimes is poverty.
raw.author: George Bernard Shaw
raw.note: From the preface to 'Major Barbara', a provocative statement that frames poverty itself as the ultimate social crime.

raw.text: A hungry man is not a free man.
raw.author: Adlai Stevenson II
raw.note: A statement on how economic necessity can eliminate true freedom of choice.

raw.text: The poor man is not he who has little, but he who desires more.
raw.author: Seneca
raw.note: A Stoic definition of poverty as a state of mind (insatiable desire) rather than a material condition.

raw.text: The poverty of the poor is not a call to charity, but a demand for justice.
raw.author: Gustavo Gutiérrez
raw.note: A key tenet of liberation theology, reframing poverty as a matter of social and economic justice.

raw.text: The poor you will always have with you.
raw.author: Jesus Christ (Matthew 26:11)
raw.note: A famous and often debated biblical passage, sometimes interpreted as a statement on the inevitability of poverty, or as a call to constant charity.

raw.text: The only thing that can be done for the poor is to abolish poverty.
raw.author: George Bernard Shaw
raw.note: A call for systemic solutions rather than palliative measures.

raw.text: The poor man's budget is a tragedy.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple statement on the impossible choices and constant sacrifices faced by those with insufficient income.

raw.text: The rich get richer and the poor get children.
raw.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
raw.note: A cynical observation from 'The Great Gatsby' on the differing realities of social classes.

raw.text: The poor are the only ones who know the value of money.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement suggesting that those who lack money have the keenest appreciation for its importance.

raw.text: The poor man's wisdom is his poverty.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb suggesting that the experience of poverty itself imparts a unique and valuable form of wisdom.

raw.text: The poor man's wealth is his children.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb that finds value and richness in family and relationships, often in the absence of material wealth.

raw.text: The poor man's prayer is his work.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the spiritual and existential significance of labor for those who have little else.

raw.text: The poor man's justice is his patience.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb on the endurance and forbearance required of the poor in an unjust world.

raw.text: The poor man's hope is his courage.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement that for the poor, hope is not a passive wish but an active act of bravery.

raw.text: The poor man's dignity is his pride.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the importance of self-respect and pride as a form of dignity for those in poverty.

raw.text: The poor man's strength is his resilience.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the incredible capacity for endurance and recovery found among the poor.

raw.text: The poor man's freedom is his lack of possessions.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A paradoxical proverb suggesting that a lack of material goods can bring a form of freedom from attachment.

raw.text: The poor man's art is his ingenuity.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the creativity and resourcefulness born of necessity.

raw.text: The poor man's philosophy is his experience.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement that lived experience is the most profound source of wisdom for the poor.

raw.text: The poor man's library is his memory.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the importance of oral tradition and memory in cultures without widespread literacy or access to books.

raw.text: The poor man's doctor is his hope.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the power of hope as a source of healing and resilience in the absence of medical care.

raw.text: The poor man's lawyer is his honesty.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb suggesting that integrity is the best defense for those who cannot afford legal representation.

raw.text: The poor man's garden is his window box.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on finding beauty and sustenance in small, humble spaces.

raw.text: The poor man's music is the sound of his own heart.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A poetic metaphor for the inner life and spirit of the poor.

raw.text: The poor man's feast is a full stomach.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A simple statement on the profound joy of satisfying basic hunger.

raw.text: The poor man's friend is the one who gives him a job.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A pragmatic view on the most valuable form of help for someone in poverty.

raw.text: The poor man's enemy is the one who gives him a handout.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A controversial proverb suggesting that charity without opportunity can create dependency and undermine dignity.

raw.text: The poor man's burden is the rich man's luxury.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the starkly different realities and values of the rich and poor.

raw.text: The poor man's curse is the rich man's blessing.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cynical proverb on the exploitative nature of wealth inequality.

raw.text: The poor man's dream is the rich man's reality.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the vast gap in aspirations and lived experience between the rich and poor.

raw.text: The poor man's reality is the rich man's nightmare.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the fear and avoidance of poverty by the wealthy.

raw.text: The poor man's life is a rich man's lesson.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the potential for the wealthy to learn humility and wisdom from the experience of the poor.

raw.text: The poor man's death is a rich man's statistic.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cynical and tragic observation on the dehumanization of the poor.

raw.text: The poor man's voice is a rich man's whisper.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the unequal power and influence of the rich and poor in society.

raw.text: The poor man's child is a rich man's servant.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A stark statement on the perpetuation of class structures across generations.

raw.text: The poor man's wife is a rich man's mistress.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cynical and misogynistic proverb on the sexual exploitation of the poor by the wealthy.

raw.text: The poor man's house is a rich man's stable.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the vast difference in living standards between the rich and poor.

raw.text: A friend is someone who knows the song in your heart and can sing it back to you when you have forgotten the words.
raw.author: C.S. Lewis
raw.note: A beautiful metaphor for the role of a true friend in reminding us of our own identity and worth.

raw.text: Friendship is born at that moment when one person says to another, 'What! You too? I thought I was the only one.'
raw.author: C.S. Lewis
raw.note: From 'The Four Loves', a famous description of the moment of recognition and shared experience that sparks friendship.

raw.text: There is nothing on this earth more to be prized than true friendship.
raw.author: Thomas Aquinas
raw.note: A medieval philosopher's statement on the supreme value of friendship.

raw.text: A friend is someone who gives you total freedom to be yourself.
raw.author: Jim Morrison
raw.note: A definition of friendship based on unconditional acceptance and the freedom of authenticity.

raw.text: A real friend is one who walks in when the rest of the world walks out.
raw.author: Walter Winchell
raw.note: A classic definition of friendship based on loyalty in times of adversity.

raw.text: Friendship is the hardest thing in the world to explain. It's not something you learn in school. But if you haven't learned the meaning of friendship, you really haven't learned anything.
raw.author: Muhammad Ali
