raw.note: A quote on the profound, experiential, and essential nature of understanding friendship.

raw.text: Don't walk behind me; I may not lead. Don't walk in front of me; I may not follow. Just walk beside me and be my friend.
raw.author: Albert Camus
raw.note: A famous quote on the nature of friendship as a relationship of equals.

raw.text: The language of friendship is not words but meanings.
raw.author: Henry David Thoreau
raw.note: A transcendentalist view that true friendship operates on a level of deep, unspoken understanding.

raw.text: A friend to all is a friend to none.
raw.author: Aristotle
raw.note: An ancient observation on the nature of true friendship, suggesting it requires specificity and cannot be universally distributed.

raw.text: The community is the best guarantee of a man's life.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb on the protective and life-sustaining power of a strong community.

raw.text: It is one of the blessings of old friends that you can afford to be stupid with them.
raw.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
raw.note: A reflection on the comfort and lack of pretense that characterize long-standing friendships.

raw.text: True friendship comes when the silence between two people is comfortable.
raw.author: David Tyson Gentry
raw.note: A modern definition of deep friendship based on the ability to share silence without awkwardness.

raw.text: A friend is a gift you give yourself.
raw.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
raw.note: A perspective that frames friendship as an act of self-care and personal enrichment.

raw.text: In the end, we will remember not the words of our enemies, but the silence of our friends.
raw.author: Martin Luther King Jr.
raw.note: A powerful statement on the pain of betrayal and the moral failure of friends who remain silent in the face of injustice.

raw.text: The best mirror is an old friend.
raw.author: George Herbert
raw.note: A proverb suggesting that a long-term friend provides the most honest and insightful reflection of oneself.

raw.text: Friendship is unnecessary, like philosophy, like art... It has no survival value; rather it is one of those things which give value to survival.
raw.author: C.S. Lewis
raw.note: From 'The Four Loves', a profound distinction between things necessary for life and things that make life worth living.

raw.text: A loyal friend laughs at your jokes when they're not so good, and sympathizes with your problems when they're not so bad.
raw.author: Arnold H. Glasow
raw.note: A humorous and heartfelt definition of a loyal friend's supportive nature.

raw.text: The greatest gift of life is friendship, and I have received it.
raw.author: Hubert H. Humphrey
raw.note: A simple and powerful statement of gratitude for the gift of friendship.

raw.text: A single rose can be my garden... a single friend, my world.
raw.author: Leo Buscaglia
raw.note: A metaphor for the immense value and world-encompassing nature of a true friend.

raw.text: Friendship marks a life even more deeply than love. Love risks degenerating into obsession, friendship is never anything but sharing.
raw.author: Elie Wiesel
raw.note: A perspective that elevates friendship above romantic love due to its foundation in sharing rather than possession.

raw.text: The circle of friendship is a place of warmth and caring, where people come together for listening and sharing.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple definition of a supportive friend group.

raw.text: A true friend is someone who is there for you when he'd rather be anywhere else.
raw.author: Len Wein
raw.note: A definition of friendship based on sacrifice and loyalty.

raw.text: Friendship is the only cement that will ever hold the world together.
raw.author: Woodrow Wilson
raw.note: A political leader's view on the foundational importance of friendship and cooperation for global peace.

raw.text: A friend is one who overlooks your broken fence and admires the flowers in your garden.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A popular metaphor for a friend's ability to see the best in you, despite your flaws.

raw.text: True friends are like diamonds — bright, beautiful, valuable, and always in style.
raw.author: Nicole Richie
raw.note: A modern and glamorous metaphor for the value of true friendship.

raw.text: The antidote for fifty enemies is one friend.
raw.author: Aristotle
raw.note: An ancient statement on the immense power of a single true friendship to overcome adversity.

raw.text: There are no strangers here; Only friends you haven't yet met.
raw.author: William Butler Yeats
raw.note: A famous and optimistic perspective on the potential for connection with all people.

raw.text: A friend is someone who makes it easy to believe in yourself.
raw.author: Heidi Wills
raw.note: A definition of a friend as a source of encouragement and self-confidence.

raw.text: The greatest healing therapy is friendship and love.
raw.author: Hubert H. Humphrey
raw.note: A statement on the restorative and therapeutic power of human connection.

raw.text: The most beautiful discovery true friends make is that they can grow separately without growing apart.
raw.author: Elisabeth Foley
raw.note: A reflection on how the strongest friendships can endure individual growth and change.

raw.text: Friendship consists in forgetting what one gives and remembering what one receives.
raw.author: Alexandre Dumas
raw.note: A definition of friendship based on generosity and gratitude.

raw.text: A friend is one of the nicest things you can have, and one of the best things you can be.
raw.author: Douglas Pagels
raw.note: A simple and heartwarming statement on the dual nature of friendship as both a gift received and a role to embody.

raw.text: A true friend never gets in your way unless you happen to be going down.
raw.author: Arnold H. Glasow
raw.note: A witty definition of a true friend as someone who supports your freedom but intervenes when you are in trouble.

raw.text: Friendship is a sheltering tree.
raw.author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge
raw.note: A simple and beautiful metaphor for the protective and nurturing nature of friendship.

raw.text: The only service a friend can really render is to keep up your courage by holding up to you a mirror in which you can see a noble image of yourself.
raw.author: George Bernard Shaw
raw.note: A philosophical view of a friend's role as a source of encouragement and a reflection of one's best self.

raw.text: True friendship is a plant of slow growth.
raw.author: George Washington
raw.note: A metaphor suggesting that deep, genuine friendship takes time and careful cultivation to develop.

raw.text: A friend is a second self.
raw.author: Aristotle
raw.note: A concise and profound definition of the deep identification found in true friendship.

raw.text: The golden rule of friendship is to listen to others as you would have them listen to you.
raw.author: David Augsburger
raw.note: An application of the classic ethical rule to the specific practice of friendship.

raw.text: A friend is someone who understands your past, believes in your future, and accepts you just the way you are.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A popular and comprehensive definition of a true friend.

raw.text: Friendship is the wine of life.
raw.author: Edward Young
raw.note: A metaphor for friendship as something that enriches life and improves with age.

raw.text: A good friend is like a four-leaf clover; hard to find and lucky to have.
raw.author: Irish Proverb
raw.note: A traditional proverb on the rarity and good fortune of true friendship.

raw.text: The friendship that can cease has never been real.
raw.author: St. Jerome
raw.note: A theological and philosophical view that true friendship is, by its nature, permanent.

raw.text: Friends are the siblings God never gave us.
raw.author: Mencius
raw.note: An ancient Chinese philosopher's take on the familial nature of deep friendship.

raw.text: The world is round so that friendship may encircle it.
raw.author: Pierre Teilhard de Chardin
raw.note: A mystical and poetic view of friendship as a global, unifying force.

raw.text: Friendship is a single soul dwelling in two bodies.
raw.author: Aristotle
raw.note: A slight variation of his famous definition of friendship.

raw.text: A friend may be waiting behind a stranger's face.
raw.author: Maya Angelou
raw.note: An optimistic encouragement to be open to new connections.

raw.text: The real test of friendship is: can you literally do nothing with the other person? Can you enjoy those moments of life that are utterly simple?
raw.author: Eugene Kennedy
raw.note: A definition of deep friendship based on the ability to share simple, quiet moments.

raw.text: Friendship is the comfort of knowing that even when you feel alone, you aren't.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple and powerful statement on the security and comfort provided by friendship.

raw.text: It is easier to forgive an enemy than to forgive a friend.
raw.author: William Blake
raw.note: A profound observation on the deep pain of betrayal by a friend, which can be harder to overcome than the actions of an adversary.

raw.text: The man of knowledge must be able not only to love his enemies but also to hate his friends.
raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
raw.note: A challenging philosophical statement suggesting that true intellectual independence requires the courage to oppose even those you are close to.

raw.text: A friendship that can end never really began.
raw.author: Publilius Syrus
raw.note: An ancient maxim suggesting that the nature of true friendship is permanence.

raw.text: No person is your friend who demands your silence, or denies your right to grow.
raw.author: Alice Walker
raw.note: A powerful definition of a toxic friendship, highlighting the dangers of suppression and stagnation.

raw.text: The most dangerous creature on this earth is a fake friend.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A stark warning about the potential harm that can be caused by betrayal from someone you trust.

raw.text: An honest enemy is better than a false friend.
raw.author: German Proverb
raw.note: A proverb valuing the clarity of open opposition over the deceit of a disloyal friend.

raw.text: Friendship is delicate as a glass, once broken it can be fixed but there will always be cracks.
raw.author: Waqar Ahmed
raw.note: A metaphor for the lasting damage that betrayal can inflict on a friendship, even if reconciliation occurs.

raw.text: The death of a friend is equivalent to the loss of a limb.
raw.author: German Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the profound and permanent sense of loss that comes with losing a close friend.

raw.text: The worst solitude is to be destitute of sincere friendship.
raw.author: Francis Bacon
raw.note: A philosophical view that the deepest form of loneliness is not being alone, but lacking true friends.

raw.text: The company of fools may first make us smile, but in the end we always feel sorrow.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cautionary proverb on the ultimate emptiness and danger of surrounding oneself with foolish company.

raw.text: A thousand friends are not enough, one enemy is too many.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb highlighting the disproportionate impact of a single enemy compared to many friends.

raw.text: A friend's eye is a good mirror.
raw.author: Irish Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the important role of a friend in providing an honest reflection of ourselves.

raw.text: He who has a thousand friends has not a friend to spare, And he who has one enemy will meet him everywhere.
raw.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
raw.note: A poetic expansion on the idea that one enemy can feel more present and impactful than many friends.

raw.text: It is more shameful to distrust our friends than to be deceived by them.
raw.author: Confucius
raw.note: An ethical stance that prioritizes the virtue of trust in a friendship, even at the risk of betrayal.

raw.text: False friendship, like the ivy, decays and ruins the walls it embraces; but true friendship gives new life and animation to the object it supports.
raw.author: Richard Burton
raw.note: A powerful metaphor contrasting the destructive nature of false friendship with the supportive nature of true friendship.

raw.text: The capacity for friendship is God's way of apologizing for our families.
raw.author: Jay McInerney
raw.note: A humorous and cynical take on friendship as a compensation for the imperfections of family life.

raw.text: A man should choose a friend who is better than himself. There are plenty of acquaintances in the world; but very few real friends.
raw.author: Chinese Proverb
raw.note: A piece of wisdom on the importance of choosing friends who inspire personal growth.

raw.text: Friendship is a responsibility, not an opportunity.
raw.author: Kahlil Gibran
raw.note: A philosophical view that reframes friendship as a duty and a commitment, rather than something to be exploited.

raw.text: The friend who can be silent with us in a moment of despair or confusion, who can stay with us in an hour of grief and bereavement, who can tolerate not knowing... not healing, not curing... that is a friend who cares.
raw.author: Henri Nouwen
raw.note: A theological perspective on the profound importance of presence and silent support in friendship.

raw.text: A friend is one to whom one may pour out the contents of one's heart, chaff and grain together, knowing that gentle hands will take and sift it, keep what is worth keeping, and with a breath of kindness, blow the rest away.
raw.author: George Eliot
raw.note: A beautiful and detailed metaphor for the trust and non-judgmental acceptance found in true friendship.

raw.text: The greatest danger of a new friend is that he will make you forget your old ones.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cautionary proverb on the importance of maintaining long-standing friendships.

raw.text: A friend in power is a friend lost.
raw.author: Henry Adams
raw.note: A cynical observation on how power and status can corrupt and destroy friendships.

raw.text: The road to a friend's house is never long.
raw.author: Danish Proverb
raw.note: A proverb on how the effort to see a friend feels insignificant because of the value of the relationship.

raw.text: A friendship founded on business is better than a business founded on friendship.
raw.author: John D. Rockefeller
raw.note: A pragmatic piece of advice suggesting that professional relationships can safely evolve into friendships, but the reverse is often dangerous.

raw.text: The best time to make friends is before you need them.
raw.author: Ethel Barrymore
raw.note: A piece of practical wisdom on the importance of building relationships based on genuine connection, not need.

raw.text: A man's friendships are one of the best measures of his worth.
raw.author: Charles Darwin
raw.note: A scientist's observation that the quality of one's character can be judged by the quality of one's friends.

raw.text: The friendship of a great man is a gift of the gods.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the immense value and good fortune of being friends with a person of great character or wisdom.

raw.text: The friendship of a fool is a dangerous thing.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cautionary proverb on the risks of associating with foolish people.

raw.text: The friendship of a good man is an education.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the educational and character-building value of a virtuous friend.

raw.text: The friendship of a wise man is a shield.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the protective and guiding nature of a wise friend.

raw.text: The friendship of a rich man is a lottery.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cynical proverb on the unpredictable and often self-serving nature of friendships with the wealthy.

raw.text: The friendship of a poor man is a treasure.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb suggesting that the friendship of someone without material wealth is often more genuine and valuable.

raw.text: The friendship of a woman is a gift from heaven.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A traditional proverb on the perceived special value of female friendship.

raw.text: The friendship of a man is a rock.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A traditional proverb on the perceived strength and stability of male friendship.

raw.text: The friendship of a child is a lesson in love.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the pure and unconditional nature of a child's friendship.

raw.text: The friendship of an old man is a blessing.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A proverb on the wisdom and value of friendship with the elderly.

raw.text: The friendship of a dog is a gift of loyalty.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the unconditional love and loyalty found in the companionship of a dog.

raw.text: The friendship of a cat is a lesson in patience.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A humorous and wise observation on the independent and earned nature of a cat's affection.

raw.text: The friendship of a book is a quiet conversation.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the companionship and wisdom found in reading.

raw.text: The friendship of a tree is a lesson in stillness.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A poetic metaphor for the peace and stability found in nature.

raw.text: The friendship of a river is a lesson in flow.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the wisdom of adapting to change, learned from observing nature.

raw.text: The friendship of a mountain is a lesson in strength.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the endurance and stability that can be learned from nature.

raw.text: The friendship of the sea is a lesson in depth.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the profound and mysterious nature of both the ocean and deep connection.

raw.text: The friendship of the sky is a lesson in perspective.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the sense of scale and perspective gained from contemplating the vastness of the sky.

raw.text: The friendship of the sun is a lesson in warmth.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the life-giving and joyful nature of a good friendship.

raw.text: The friendship of the moon is a lesson in cycles.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the natural ebb and flow of life and relationships.

raw.text: The friendship of the stars is a lesson in wonder.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the sense of awe and inspiration that can come from a deep connection.

raw.text: The friendship of a song is a memory of a feeling.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the power of music to evoke and preserve the emotions of past friendships.

raw.text: The friendship of a fire is a lesson in comfort.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the warmth, safety, and companionship provided by a good friend.

raw.text: The friendship of a road is a lesson in journey.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the shared experiences and adventures that define a friendship.

raw.text: The heart has its reasons of which reason knows nothing.
raw.author: Blaise Pascal
raw.note: A famous philosophical statement on the irrational and intuitive nature of love and faith.

raw.text: To love and be loved is to feel the sun from both sides.
raw.author: David Viscott
raw.note: A beautiful metaphor for the reciprocal warmth and joy of mutual love.

raw.text: The greatest happiness of life is the conviction that we are loved; loved for ourselves, or rather, loved in spite of ourselves.
raw.author: Victor Hugo
raw.note: From 'Les Misérables', a profound insight into the power of unconditional love.

raw.text: Love does not consist in gazing at each other, but in looking outward together in the same direction.
raw.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
raw.note: A definition of mature love based on shared goals and a common purpose, rather than just mutual admiration.

raw.text: The giving of love is an education in itself.
raw.author: Eleanor Roosevelt
raw.note: A perspective on the personal growth and learning that comes from the act of loving others.

raw.text: The pain of parting is nothing to the joy of meeting again.
raw.author: Charles Dickens
raw.note: From 'Nicholas Nickleby', an optimistic view on the joy of reunion after a painful separation.

raw.text: It is better to have loved and lost than never to have loved at all.
raw.author: Alfred Lord Tennyson
raw.note: A famous line from 'In Memoriam A.H.H.', arguing that the experience of love is worth the inevitable pain of loss.

raw.text: There is always some madness in love. But there is also always some reason in madness.
raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
raw.note: A philosophical observation on the interplay of passion and reason within love.

raw.text: Love is composed of a single soul inhabiting two bodies.
raw.author: Aristotle
raw.note: A classic definition of deep love and friendship as a spiritual union.

raw.text: The course of true love never did run smooth.
raw.author: William Shakespeare
raw.note: A famous line from 'A Midsummer Night's Dream' on the inherent difficulties and obstacles in romantic love.

raw.text: To be brave is to love someone unconditionally, without expecting anything in return.
raw.author: Madonna
raw.note: A modern definition of courage as the act of selfless, unconditional love.

raw.text: Love is an irresistible desire to be irresistibly desired.
raw.author: Robert Frost
raw.note: A witty and insightful definition of the reciprocal nature of romantic desire.

raw.text: The heart was made to be broken.
raw.author: Oscar Wilde
raw.note: A cynical and tragic view of heartbreak as an inevitable part of the human condition.

raw.text: The hottest love has the coldest end.
raw.author: Socrates
raw.note: An ancient observation on the tendency for the most passionate romances to end in the most painful heartbreak.

raw.text: We accept the love we think we deserve.
raw.author: Stephen Chbosky
raw.note: From 'The Perks of Being a Wallflower', a psychological insight into how self-esteem shapes our relationships.

raw.text: Love is a fire. But whether it is going to warm your hearth or burn down your house, you can never tell.
raw.author: Joan Crawford
raw.note: A powerful metaphor for the dual, unpredictable nature of love as either comforting or destructive.

raw.text: The pleasure of love is in loving. We are happier in the passion we feel than in that which we inspire.
raw.author: François de La Rochefoucauld
raw.note: A philosophical reflection suggesting that the act of giving love is more fulfilling than receiving it.

raw.text: Never love anybody who treats you like you're ordinary.
raw.author: Oscar Wilde
raw.note: A piece of advice on self-worth in relationships, advocating for a love that recognizes one's uniqueness.

raw.text: To love at all is to be vulnerable.
raw.author: C.S. Lewis
raw.note: From 'The Four Loves', a statement on the inherent risk and vulnerability required to love.

raw.text: The only thing we never get enough of is love; and the only thing we never give enough of is love.
raw.author: Henry Miller
raw.note: A reflection on the infinite capacity for both giving and receiving love.

raw.text: Love is an action, never simply a feeling.
raw.author: bell hooks
raw.note: A definition of love as a practice and a choice, not just a passive emotion.

raw.text: The way to love anything is to realize that it may be lost.
raw.author: G.K. Chesterton
raw.note: A paradoxical insight that a deep appreciation for something comes from understanding its impermanence.

raw.text: Love is the master key that opens the gates of happiness.
raw.author: Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr.
raw.note: A simple and powerful metaphor for love as the essential element for a happy life.

raw.text: The greatest weakness of most humans is their hesitancy to tell others how much they love them while they're still alive.
raw.author: Orlando A. Battista
raw.note: A poignant observation on the tragedy of unspoken love.

raw.text: To be fully seen by somebody, then, and be loved anyhow—this is a human offering that can border on miraculous.
raw.author: Elizabeth Gilbert
raw.note: From 'Eat, Pray, Love', a modern reflection on the profound gift of unconditional acceptance.

raw.text: You know you're in love when you can't fall asleep because reality is finally better than your dreams.
raw.author: Dr. Seuss
raw.note: A famous and whimsical definition of the exhilarating feeling of being in love.

raw.text: Love is a better teacher than duty.
raw.author: Albert Einstein
raw.note: A statement that actions motivated by love are more powerful and effective than those motivated by obligation.

raw.text: The heart has its own memory, and I have forgotten nothing.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the enduring power of emotional memory, especially in matters of love and loss.

raw.text: The most painful thing is losing yourself in the process of loving someone too much, and forgetting that you are special too.
raw.author: Ernest Hemingway
raw.note: A cautionary quote on the danger of losing one's own identity in a relationship.

raw.text: Love is not finding someone to live with; it's finding someone you can't live without.
raw.author: Rafael Ortiz
raw.note: A popular definition of deep, indispensable love.

raw.text: The art of love is largely the art of persistence.
raw.author: Albert Ellis
raw.note: A psychologist's pragmatic view of love as something that requires continuous effort and perseverance.

raw.text: A broken heart is just the growing pains necessary so that you can love more completely when the real thing comes along.
raw.author: J.S.B. Morse
raw.note: An optimistic reframing of heartbreak as a necessary experience for future growth in love.

raw.text: The best love is the kind that awakens the soul; that makes us reach for more, that plants the fire in our hearts and brings peace to our minds.
raw.author: Nicholas Sparks
raw.note: From 'The Notebook', a romantic and aspirational definition of transformative love.

raw.text: Love is an untamed force. When we try to control it, it destroys us. When we try to imprison it, it enslaves us. When we try to understand it, it leaves us feeling lost and confused.
raw.author: Paulo Coelho
raw.note: A reflection on the powerful and uncontrollable nature of love.

raw.text: The best and most beautiful things in this world cannot be seen or even heard, but must be felt with the heart.
raw.author: Helen Keller
raw.note: A profound insight on the nature of love and other deep emotions as things that transcend the physical senses.

raw.text: To love is to burn, to be on fire.
raw.author: Jane Austen
raw.note: From 'Mansfield Park', a simple and powerful metaphor for the passionate intensity of love.

raw.text: Love is the strange bewilderment which overtakes one person on account of another person.
raw.author: James Thurber
raw.note: A humorous and slightly baffled definition of the state of being in love.

raw.text: The heart has its own language. The heart knows a hundred thousand ways to speak.
raw.author: Rumi
raw.note: A mystical perspective on the deep and varied ways the heart communicates.

raw.text: The only thing worse than a boy who hates you: a boy that loves you.
raw.author: Markus Zusak
raw.note: From 'The Book Thief', a poignant reflection on the vulnerability and potential for pain that comes with love.

raw.text: There is never a time or place for true love. It happens accidentally, in a heartbeat, in a single flashing, throbbing moment.
raw.author: Sarah Dessen
raw.note: A modern author's take on the spontaneous and sudden nature of falling in love.

raw.text: The saddest thing about love is that not only that it cannot last forever, but that heartbreak is soon forgotten.
raw.author: William Faulkner
raw.note: A pessimistic and complex view on the impermanence of both love and the pain of its loss.

raw.text: Love is an emotion experienced by the many and enjoyed by the few.
raw.author: George Jean Nathan
raw.note: A cynical critique on the difference between the idea of love and the reality of a successful, happy relationship.

raw.text: The cure for a broken heart is simple, my lady. A new one.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical but common piece of advice on moving on from heartbreak.

raw.text: The heart is the only broken instrument that works.
raw.author: T.E. Kalem
raw.note: A hopeful metaphor for the resilience of the human heart, which can continue to love even after being broken.

raw.text: The emotion that can break your heart is sometimes the very one that heals it.
raw.author: Nicholas Sparks
raw.note: A reflection on the dual nature of love as both the cause of and cure for heartbreak.

raw.text: The heart will break, but broken live on.
raw.author: Lord Byron
raw.note: A Romantic poet's statement on the resilience of life in the face of heartbreak.

raw.text: The shattering of a heart when being broken is the loudest quiet ever.
raw.author: Carroll Bryant
raw.note: A poetic description of the silent, internal devastation of heartbreak.

raw.text: The only thing a boyfriend was good for was a shattered heart.
raw.author: Becca Fitzpatrick
raw.note: A cynical and humorous line from the young adult novel 'Hush, Hush'.

raw.text: Choose a job you love, and you will never have to work a day in your life.
raw.author: Confucius
raw.note: An ancient piece of wisdom on the joy of finding a vocation that aligns with one's passion.

raw.text: Pleasure in the job puts perfection in the work.
raw.author: Aristotle
raw.note: An ancient philosophical observation on the link between job satisfaction and high-quality work.

raw.text: It's not the hours you put in your work that counts, it's the work you put in the hours.
raw.author: Sam Ewing
raw.note: A statement on the importance of focused, effective effort over simply being present.

raw.text: The man who is a master of patience is master of everything else.
raw.author: George Savile
raw.note: A piece of wisdom on the power of patience as a key virtue for success in work and life.

raw.text: The world is full of willing people; some willing to work, the rest willing to let them.
raw.author: Robert Frost
raw.note: A cynical and humorous observation on the distribution of work ethic in society.

raw.text: The reward for work well done is the opportunity to do more.
raw.author: Jonas Salk
raw.note: A perspective from a great scientist that the true reward for success is the chance to tackle new challenges.

raw.text: A professional is someone who can do his best work when he doesn't feel like it.
raw.author: Alistair Cooke
raw.note: A definition of professionalism based on discipline and consistency, regardless of mood.

raw.text: The best way to learn mathematics is to do mathematics.
raw.author: Paul Halmos
raw.note: A statement on the active, participatory nature of learning a skill-based profession.

raw.text: Silence is the language of God, all else is poor translation.
raw.author: Rumi
raw.note: A mystical perspective that positions silence as the ultimate form of divine communication, beyond the limits of human language.

raw.text: The cruelest lies are often told in silence.
raw.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
raw.note: A powerful observation on the danger of silence, suggesting that withholding the truth can be a profound form of deceit.

raw.text: I have often regretted my speech, never my silence.
raw.author: Publilius Syrus
raw.note: An ancient Roman maxim on the wisdom of restraint in speech.

raw.text: Silence is a source of great strength.
raw.author: Lao Tzu
raw.note: A Taoist principle on the power that can be cultivated from inner stillness and quiet.

raw.text: He who does not understand your silence will probably not understand your words.
raw.author: Elbert Hubbard
raw.note: A statement on the deep level of connection required for non-verbal understanding between people.

raw.text: Work hard in silence, let your success be your noise.
raw.author: Frank Ocean
raw.note: A modern piece of advice on focusing on diligent work privately and letting the results speak for themselves.

raw.text: Silence is the most powerful scream.
raw.author: Anonymous
raw.note: A paradoxical statement often attributed to various sources, highlighting the immense communicative power of silence, especially in protest or grief.

raw.text: The right word may be effective, but no word was ever as effective as a rightly timed pause.
raw.author: Mark Twain
raw.note: A writer's insight into the rhetorical power of silence in communication.

raw.text: Silence is the sleep that nourishes wisdom.
raw.author: Francis Bacon
raw.note: A metaphor for the restorative and generative power of silence in the cultivation of wisdom.

raw.text: Through the portals of silence, the healing sun of wisdom and peace will shine upon you.
raw.author: Paramahansa Yogananda
raw.note: A spiritual perspective on silence as a gateway to inner peace and enlightenment.

raw.text: Silence is the element in which great things fashion themselves together.
raw.author: Thomas Carlyle
raw.note: A reflection on the necessity of a quiet, contemplative environment for the creation of significant work.

raw.text: Silence is a true friend who never betrays.
raw.author: Confucius
raw.note: An ancient philosopher's view on the reliability and safety of silence compared to speech.

raw.text: The quieter you become, the more you can hear.
raw.author: Ram Dass
raw.note: A simple and profound teaching on how inner and outer silence enhances one's perception.

raw.text: I think the first virtue is to restrain the tongue; he approaches nearest to the gods who knows how to be silent, even though he is in the right.
raw.author: Cato the Elder
raw.note: An ancient Roman statesman's view on the supreme virtue of knowing when to remain silent.

raw.text: Silence is the ultimate weapon of power.
raw.author: Charles de Gaulle
raw.note: A political leader's perspective on the strategic use of silence to command respect and maintain an advantage.

raw.text: Well-timed silence hath more eloquence than speech.
raw.author: Martin Farquhar Tupper
raw.note: A poetic observation on the superior communicative power of a strategic pause.

raw.text: The human heart has hidden treasures, In secret kept, in silence sealed.
raw.author: Charlotte Brontë
raw.note: A reflection on the private, silent nature of our deepest emotions and secrets.

raw.text: Silence is the mother of truth.
raw.author: Benjamin Disraeli
raw.note: A statement suggesting that truth is often found in quiet contemplation, away from the noise of deception.

raw.text: Silence is one of the great arts of conversation.
raw.author: Marcus Tullius Cicero
raw.note: An ancient orator's insight into the importance of listening and pausing in effective communication.

raw.text: Nothing strengthens authority so much as silence.
raw.author: Leonardo da Vinci
raw.note: A Renaissance artist and thinker's observation on the power of silence to command respect and project authority.

raw.text: He who knows, does not speak. He who speaks, does not know.
raw.author: Lao Tzu
raw.note: A famous Taoist paradox suggesting that true wisdom is often silent, while empty speech signifies ignorance.

raw.text: Silence is the great teacher, and to learn its lessons you must pay attention to it.
raw.author: Deepak Chopra
raw.note: A modern spiritual perspective on the wisdom that can be gained from practicing silence.

raw.text: The eternal silence of these infinite spaces frightens me.
raw.author: Blaise Pascal
raw.note: A famous expression of existential dread when contemplating the vast, silent emptiness of the cosmos.

raw.text: Speech is silver, silence is golden.
raw.author: Thomas Carlyle
raw.note: The famous English popularization of an older proverb, valuing the wisdom of silence over the commonness of speech.

raw.text: Silence is a fence around wisdom.
raw.author: German Proverb
raw.note: A proverb suggesting that silence protects wisdom from being wasted or misused.

raw.text: The music is not in the notes, but in the silence between.
raw.author: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
raw.note: A composer's insight into the crucial role of rests and pauses in creating musical meaning and emotion.

raw.text: Silence is the virtue of fools.
raw.author: Francis Bacon
raw.note: A contrary view, suggesting that silence can sometimes be a mask for ignorance rather than wisdom.

raw.text: The most significant conversations of our lives occur in silence.
raw.author: Simon Van Booy
raw.note: A modern author's reflection on the power of non-verbal communication and shared understanding.

raw.text: Silence is not empty. It's full of answers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A spiritual perspective that reframes silence as a space of profound insight.

raw.text: True silence is the rest of the mind; it is to the spirit what sleep is to the body, nourishment and refreshment.
raw.author: William Penn
raw.note: A Quaker leader's view on the restorative and nourishing power of mental and spiritual silence.

raw.text: A reader lives a thousand lives before he dies . . . The man who never reads lives only one.
raw.author: George R.R. Martin
raw.note: From 'A Dance with Dragons', a famous quote on how reading expands our experience of life.

raw.text: There is no friend as loyal as a book.
raw.author: Ernest Hemingway
raw.note: A simple and powerful statement on the constant and reliable companionship found in books.

raw.text: You can never get a cup of tea large enough or a book long enough to suit me.
raw.author: C.S. Lewis
raw.note: A beloved quote expressing a deep and insatiable love for reading and comfort.

raw.text: A room without books is like a body without a soul.
raw.author: Marcus Tullius Cicero
raw.note: An ancient Roman statesman's metaphor for the essential, life-giving role of books in a home.

raw.text: If you only read the books that everyone else is reading, you can only think what everyone else is thinking.
raw.author: Haruki Murakami
raw.note: From 'Norwegian Wood', a call for independent reading as a path to independent thought.

raw.text: A book is a dream that you hold in your hand.
raw.author: Neil Gaiman
raw.note: A simple and beautiful metaphor for the imaginative power of books.

raw.text: I have always imagined that Paradise will be a kind of library.
raw.author: Jorge Luis Borges
raw.note: A famous expression of the ultimate value and pleasure of books and knowledge.

raw.text: There are worse crimes than burning books. One of them is not reading them.
raw.author: Joseph Brodsky
raw.note: A powerful statement on the cultural and personal crime of neglecting the knowledge contained in books.

raw.text: A book is a device to ignite the imagination.
raw.author: Alan Bennett
raw.note: A concise definition of a book's primary function as a catalyst for creativity.

raw.text: The stories we love best do live in us forever.
raw.author: J.K. Rowling
raw.note: A reflection on the lasting and formative impact of beloved narratives.

raw.text: Reading is a discount ticket to everywhere.
raw.author: Mary Schmich
raw.note: A witty and accurate description of reading as an affordable means of travel and exploration.

raw.text: A good book is an event in my life.
raw.author: Stendhal
raw.note: A statement on the profound and significant impact a truly great book can have on a reader.

raw.text: That's the thing about books. They let you travel without moving your feet.
raw.author: Jhumpa Lahiri
raw.note: From 'The Namesake', a simple and beautiful expression of the transportive power of reading.

raw.text: A classic is a book that has never finished saying what it has to say.
raw.author: Italo Calvino
raw.note: A famous definition of a classic as a work of literature with enduring relevance and inexhaustible meaning.

raw.text: A book is a version of the world. If you do not like it, ignore it; or offer your own version in return.
raw.author: Salman Rushdie
raw.note: A statement on the subjective nature of literature and the creative impulse to respond to it.

raw.text: There is more treasure in books than in all the pirate's loot on Treasure Island.
raw.author: Walt Disney
raw.note: A simple and powerful metaphor for the immense value of knowledge and stories found in books.

raw.text: A book is proof that humans are capable of working magic.
raw.author: Carl Sagan
raw.note: From 'Cosmos', a scientist's view of the book as a magical technology for transmitting consciousness across time.

raw.text: I think of life as a good book. The further you get into it, the more it begins to make sense.
raw.author: Harold Kushner
raw.note: A metaphor for life as a narrative that gains clarity and meaning with experience.

raw.text: The world was hers for the reading.
raw.author: Betty Smith
raw.note: From 'A Tree Grows in Brooklyn', a beautiful line about the power of reading to open up the world.

raw.text: A book is a garden, an orchard, a storehouse, a party, a company by the way, a counselor, a multitude of counselors.
raw.author: Henry Ward Beecher
raw.note: A rich and varied metaphor for the many roles a book can play in a person's life.

raw.text: You think your pain and your heartbreak are unprecedented in the history of the world, but then you read.
raw.author: James Baldwin
raw.note: A powerful statement on the role of literature in connecting us to the shared human experience and alleviating loneliness.

raw.text: Reading is to the mind what exercise is to the body.
raw.author: Joseph Addison
raw.note: A classic analogy for the importance of reading as a form of mental exercise.

raw.text: A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way.
raw.author: Flannery O'Connor
raw.note: A definition of storytelling as a unique and essential mode of communication.

raw.text: Books are a uniquely portable magic.
raw.author: Stephen King
raw.note: From 'On Writing', a simple and memorable description of the magical quality of books.

raw.text: The book you don't read won't help.
raw.author: Jim Rohn
raw.note: A simple and direct statement on the necessity of actually engaging with books for them to have any value.

raw.text: The world of books is the most remarkable creation of man. Nothing else that he builds ever lasts.
raw.author: Clarence Day
raw.note: A statement on the unique permanence and legacy of literature.

raw.text: Books are the quietest and most constant of friends; they are the most accessible and wisest of counselors, and the most patient of teachers.
raw.author: Charles W. Eliot
raw.note: A comprehensive tribute to the many supportive roles that books can play in our lives.

raw.text: A book is a garden carried in the pocket.
raw.author: Chinese Proverb
raw.note: A beautiful metaphor for the portable world of beauty and nourishment that a book provides.

raw.text: A book is a gift you can open again and again.
raw.author: Garrison Keillor
raw.note: A simple and heartwarming description of the reusable joy of reading.

raw.text: A book is a loaded gun in the house next door.
raw.author: Ray Bradbury
raw.note: From 'Fahrenheit 451', a powerful metaphor for the dangerous and revolutionary power of ideas contained in books.

raw.text: A book is a heart that only beats in the chest of another.
raw.author: Rebecca Solnit
raw.note: A modern, poetic metaphor for the way a book comes to life through the act of reading.

raw.text: A book is a magical thing that lets you travel to far-away places without ever leaving your chair.
raw.author: Katrina Mayer
raw.note: A simple description of the transportive magic of reading.

raw.text: A book is a mirror: if an ass peers into it, you can't expect an apostle to look out.
raw.author: Georg Christoph Lichtenberg
raw.note: A cynical and witty observation that a reader's understanding of a book is limited by their own intelligence and perspective.

raw.text: A book is a secret between the writer and the reader.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the intimate and personal nature of the reading experience.

raw.text: A book is a story for the mind, a song for the heart, and a lesson for the soul.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A tripartite definition of a book's impact on our intellect, emotions, and spirit.

raw.text: A book is a friend that never deceives.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the reliability and honesty of the knowledge found in books.

raw.text: A book is a good companion.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A simple and timeless statement on the companionship of books.

raw.text: A book is a better friend than a man.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A cynical proverb that prioritizes the reliability of books over the fallibility of human relationships.

raw.text: The important thing in science is not so much to obtain new facts as to discover new ways of thinking about them.
raw.author: William Lawrence Bragg
raw.note: A Nobel laureate's perspective on the importance of conceptual breakthroughs over mere data collection.

raw.text: Equipped with his five senses, man explores the universe around him and calls the adventure Science.
raw.author: Edwin Hubble
raw.note: A simple and poetic definition of science as the human adventure of exploration.

raw.text: Science is a way of thinking much more than it is a body of knowledge.
raw.author: Carl Sagan
raw.note: A definition of science as a process and a mindset, not just a collection of facts.

raw.text: What we know is a drop, what we don't know is an ocean.
raw.author: Isaac Newton
raw.note: A famous statement of intellectual humility from one of history's greatest scientists.

raw.text: Science is organized knowledge. Wisdom is organized life.
raw.author: Immanuel Kant
raw.note: A philosophical distinction between the structured knowledge of science and the applied wisdom of living well.

raw.text: The art and science of asking questions is the source of all knowledge.
raw.author: Thomas Berger
raw.note: A statement on the fundamental role of inquiry in the pursuit of knowledge.

raw.text: The most exciting phrase to hear in science, the one that heralds new discoveries, is not 'Eureka!' but 'That's funny...'
raw.author: Isaac Asimov
raw.note: An insight into the nature of scientific discovery, which often begins with noticing an anomaly.

raw.text: Science without religion is lame, religion without science is blind.
raw.author: Albert Einstein
raw.note: A famous statement on the complementary relationship between the empirical and the spiritual.

raw.text: The scientist is not a person who gives the right answers, he's one who asks the right questions.
raw.author: Claude Lévi-Strauss
raw.note: An anthropologist's view of the scientist's primary role as an inquirer.

raw.text: In science, 'fact' can only mean 'confirmed to such a degree that it would be perverse to withhold provisional assent.' I suppose that apples might start to rise tomorrow, but the possibility does not merit equal time in physics classrooms.
raw.author: Stephen Jay Gould
raw.note: A paleontologist's clear definition of what constitutes a scientific fact.

raw.text: A man who has committed a mistake and doesn't correct it, is committing another mistake.
raw.author: Confucius
raw.note: An ancient philosophical principle that is a cornerstone of the self-correcting nature of science.

raw.text: The scientist has a lot of experience with ignorance and doubt and uncertainty, and this experience is of very great value.
raw.author: Richard Feynman
raw.note: A perspective on the psychological value of the scientific mindset, which embraces not knowing.

raw.text: Science is the great antidote to the poison of enthusiasm and superstition.
raw.author: Adam Smith
raw.note: An Enlightenment philosopher's view of science as a force for reason against irrationality.

raw.text: The joy of insight is a sense of involvement and awe, the elated state of mind that you are beholden to, that you are a part of, that you are touching something that is vibrating with the universe.
raw.author: V. S. Ramachandran
raw.note: A neuroscientist's description of the profound emotional experience of scientific discovery.

raw.text: Research is what I'm doing when I don't know what I'm doing.
raw.author: Wernher von Braun
raw.note: A humorous and honest definition of the exploratory nature of research.

raw.text: Science is the belief in the ignorance of experts.
raw.author: Richard Feynman
raw.note: A provocative statement on the importance of skepticism and questioning authority in science.

raw.text: The aim of science is not to open a door to infinite wisdom, but to set a limit to infinite error.
raw.author: Bertolt Brecht
raw.note: From the play 'Life of Galileo', a view of science as a process of reducing error rather than achieving absolute truth.

raw.text: Science is a differential equation. Religion is a boundary condition.
raw.author: Alan Turing
raw.note: A mathematical metaphor for the relationship between science (the process) and religion (the framework or starting assumptions).

raw.text: Life is a journey, not a destination.
raw.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
raw.note: A classic metaphor emphasizing the importance of the process of living over achieving a final goal.

raw.text: Life is a game, play it; Life is a challenge, meet it; Life is a dream, realize it; Life is a sacrifice, offer it; Life is love, enjoy it.
raw.author: Sai Baba
raw.note: A spiritual perspective offering multiple metaphors for how to approach life's different facets.

raw.text: Life is a long lesson in humility.
raw.author: James M. Barrie
raw.note: A perspective that frames life as a continuous process of learning one's own limitations.

raw.text: Life is a moderately good play with a badly written third act.
raw.author: Truman Capote
raw.note: A cynical and witty metaphor for the often unsatisfying and poorly resolved nature of old age and death.

raw.text: Life is a dream for the wise, a game for the fool, a comedy for the rich, a tragedy for the poor.
raw.author: Sholom Aleichem
raw.note: A statement on how one's perspective and social standing completely change the metaphor for life.

raw.text: The world is a stage, but the play is badly cast.
raw.author: Oscar Wilde
raw.note: A cynical twist on Shakespeare's famous metaphor, critiquing the competence of the people in it.

raw.text: Life is a battle, and we are the soldiers.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A common metaphor framing life as a constant struggle against adversity.

raw.text: Life is a garden, and we are the gardeners.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for our active role in cultivating our own lives and experiences.

raw.text: Life is a river, and we are the boatmen.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for navigating the continuous and often unpredictable flow of time.

raw.text: Life is a mountain, and we are the climbers.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for life as a challenging ascent toward a goal, filled with obstacles and achievements.

raw.text: Life is a puzzle, and we are the solvers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the intellectual and existential challenge of finding meaning and understanding in life.

raw.text: Life is a song, and we are the musicians.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our role in creating the harmony, rhythm, and melody of our own lives.

raw.text: Life is a story, and we are the authors.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A narrative metaphor for our power to write our own destiny and define our own experiences.

raw.text: Life is a canvas, and we are the painters.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our creative power to shape the picture of our lives.

raw.text: Life is a fire, and we are the fuel.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our life energy being consumed in the process of living.

raw.text: Life is a storm, and we are the sailors.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for navigating the turbulent and unpredictable nature of life.

raw.text: Life is a bridge, and we are the builders.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our work in connecting our past with our desired future.

raw.text: Life is a symphony, and we are the conductors.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our role in orchestrating the various elements of our lives into a coherent whole.

raw.text: Life is a tapestry, and we are the weavers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for how our individual actions intertwine to create the fabric of our life's story.

raw.text: Life is a path, and we are the walkers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple metaphor for our journey through existence.

raw.text: Life is a question, and we are the answer.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophical framing of our existence as the answer to the question of 'how to live'.

raw.text: Life is a mirror of our choices.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the direct consequences of our decisions on the quality of our lives.

raw.text: Life is a gift, and we are the recipients.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective that frames life as a gift to be cherished with gratitude.

raw.text: Life is a challenge, and we are the contenders.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the struggles and competitions that we face in life.

raw.text: Life is a promise, and we are the promise-keepers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on our ethical duty to fulfill our own potential.

raw.text: Life is a horizon, and we are always moving towards it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the ever-receding and aspirational nature of our goals in life.

raw.text: Life is a blank page, and we hold the pen.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our agency and power to write our own life story.

raw.text: Life is a construction site, and we are the architects.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our role in designing and building our own lives.

raw.text: Life is a conversation with the universe.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A spiritual metaphor for life as an ongoing dialogue with existence itself.

raw.text: Life is a puzzle with a million pieces, and we are all trying to fit them together.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the complexity and collaborative nature of creating a meaningful life.

raw.text: Life is a garden that we must tend to daily.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the need for present care and effort to ensure a good life.

raw.text: Life is a choice between what is easy and what is right.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An ethical framing of life as a series of moral decisions.

raw.text: Life is a gift we give to ourselves.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective that frames our present efforts and choices as a gift to our future selves.

raw.text: Life is a challenge to our imagination.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the need for creativity and vision to live a full life.

raw.text: Life is a promise we make to our children.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on our intergenerational responsibility to live well.

raw.text: Life is a horizon that expands as we approach it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for how life reveals more possibilities the more we live it.

raw.text: Life is a blank canvas, and we are the colors.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our individual contributions to the overall picture of life.

raw.text: Life is a river of time, and we are all sailing on it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the inexorable flow of time in our lives.

raw.text: Life is a mountain of opportunity, and we are all climbers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An optimistic view of life as a landscape of potential achievements.

raw.text: Life is a mystery to be solved, and we are all detectives.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the human quest to understand the meaning of life.

raw.text: Life is a song to be written, and we are all composers.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our creative role in shaping our life's narrative.

raw.text: Life is a garden of possibilities, and we are all gardeners.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our role in cultivating the potential of our lives.

raw.text: Life is a fire to be stoked, and we are all keepers of the flame.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for our responsibility to maintain our own passion and vitality.

raw.text: Life is a storm to be weathered, and we are all sailors.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A realistic view of life as a series of challenges to be endured.

raw.text: Nearly all men can stand adversity, but if you want to test a man's character, give him power.
raw.author: Abraham Lincoln
raw.note: A famous observation suggesting that power is the ultimate test of a person's true character.

raw.text: The greatest leader is not necessarily the one who does the greatest things. He is the one that gets the people to do the greatest things.
raw.author: Ronald Reagan
raw.note: A definition of leadership based on empowerment and inspiration rather than personal achievement.

raw.text: Politics is the art of the possible.
raw.author: Otto von Bismarck
raw.note: A classic and pragmatic definition of politics as the practice of achieving what is feasible, not necessarily what is ideal.

raw.text: The price of greatness is responsibility.
raw.author: Winston Churchill
raw.note: A statement reflecting the belief that leadership and influence come with a heavy burden of duty and accountability.

raw.text: If your actions inspire others to dream more, learn more, do more and become more, you are a leader.
raw.author: John Quincy Adams
raw.note: A definition of leadership based on its positive and empowering influence on others.

raw.text: The art of leadership is saying no, not yes. It is very easy to say yes.
raw.author: Tony Blair
raw.note: A modern political leader's perspective on the importance of discipline and focus in leadership.

raw.text: Power is not a means; it is an end. One does not establish a dictatorship in order to safeguard a revolution; one makes the revolution in order to establish the dictatorship.
raw.author: George Orwell
raw.note: From 'Nineteen Eighty-Four', a chilling description of the totalitarian pursuit of power for its own sake.

raw.text: The supreme quality for leadership is unquestionably integrity. Without it, no real success is possible, no matter whether it is on a section gang, a football field, in an army, or in an office.
raw.author: Dwight D. Eisenhower
raw.note: A statement from a general and president on the absolute necessity of integrity for true leadership.

raw.text: The measure of a man is what he does with power.
raw.author: Plato
raw.note: An ancient philosophical view that true character is revealed by the use of power.

raw.text: Politics is war without bloodshed while war is politics with bloodshed.
raw.author: Mao Zedong
raw.note: A famous statement on the intimate and often brutal relationship between politics and warfare.

raw.text: The most dangerous man to any government is the man who is able to think things out for himself.
raw.author: H. L. Mencken
raw.note: A statement on the threat that independent thought poses to established power structures.

raw.text: A leader takes people where they want to go. A great leader takes people where they don't necessarily want to go, but ought to be.
raw.author: Rosalynn Carter
raw.note: A distinction between leadership as management and leadership as visionary guidance.

raw.text: Power is the great aphrodisiac.
raw.author: Henry Kissinger
raw.note: A famous and cynical observation on the seductive allure of power.

raw.text: The function of leadership is to produce more leaders, not more followers.
raw.author: Ralph Nader
raw.note: A definition of leadership based on empowerment and mentorship.

raw.text: Power is of two kinds. One is obtained by the fear of punishment and the other by acts of love. Power based on love is a thousand times more effective and permanent than the one derived from fear of punishment.
raw.author: Mahatma Gandhi
raw.note: A distinction between coercive power and influential power, arguing for the superiority of the latter.

raw.text: The best executive is the one who has sense enough to pick good men to do what he wants done, and self-restraint enough to keep from meddling with them while they do it.
raw.author: Theodore Roosevelt
raw.note: A definition of effective leadership based on delegation and trust.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can find a solution for every problem, and a problem for every solution.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical view of politicians as creators of unnecessary complexity and conflict.

raw.text: The politician is a person who can make you believe that he is a man of the people, even when he is a man of himself.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A cynical take on the ultimate self-interest of politicians.

raw.text: The greatest power is not money power, but political power.
raw.author: Walter Annenberg
raw.note: A perspective from a wealthy publisher, suggesting that political authority ultimately outweighs financial influence.

raw.text: All things are subject to interpretation whichever interpretation prevails at a given time is a function of power and not truth.
raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
raw.note: A key tenet of his philosophy, arguing that dominant 'truths' are established by those in power, not by objective fact.

raw.text: The problem with having a lot of power is that you have a lot of people who want it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple observation on the inherent instability and competitive nature of holding power.

raw.text: The day the power of love overrules the love of power, the world will know peace.
raw.author: Mahatma Gandhi
raw.note: A famous aphorism on the fundamental shift in values required to achieve global peace.

raw.text: You only have power over people so long as you don't take everything from them. But when you've robbed a man of everything, he's no longer in your power—he's free again.
raw.author: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn
raw.note: From 'The Gulag Archipelago', an insight into the paradoxical freedom that comes from having nothing left to lose.

raw.text: The only power you have is the power of your own thoughts.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A Stoic-like principle emphasizing that true control is internal.

raw.text: The greatest power that a person possesses is the power to choose.
raw.author: J. Martin Kohe
raw.note: A statement on the fundamental power of human agency and decision-making.

raw.text: The power of a man's virtue should not be measured by his special efforts, but by his ordinary doing.
raw.author: Blaise Pascal
raw.note: A philosophical take on character, suggesting true virtue is found in daily habits, not grand gestures.

raw.text: The power of language to shape our perceptions of reality is immense.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the formative power of language in constructing our understanding of the world.

raw.text: The power of a glance has been so much abused in love stories, that it has come to be disbelieved in.
raw.author: Stendhal
raw.note: A literary observation on how clichés can diminish the perceived power of a real human experience.

raw.text: The power of a book lies in its ability to change our minds.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the transformative intellectual and emotional power of literature.

raw.text: The power of a good idea is that it can be shared without being diminished.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An observation on the unique, non-rivalrous nature of ideas and knowledge.

raw.text: The power of a community is not in its numbers, but in its unity.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A piece of wisdom on the importance of cohesion and solidarity for collective power.

raw.text: The power of a leader is not in his authority, but in his influence.
raw.author: John C. Maxwell
raw.note: A distinction between formal authority and the true power of persuasive and inspirational leadership.

raw.text: The power of a question is that it is the beginning of an answer.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the generative power of inquiry.

raw.text: The power of a secret is that it gives you control.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An observation on how withholding information can be a source of personal and political power.

raw.text: The power of a smile is that it is a universal language.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the simple, cross-cultural power of a positive human expression.

raw.text: The power of a story is that it can change the world.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the transformative power of narrative to shape beliefs and inspire action.

raw.text: The power of a vision is that it can unite people.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the ability of a shared goal to create unity and collective action.

raw.text: The power of a whisper is that it can be louder than a shout.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the power of subtlety, secrets, and quiet influence.

raw.text: The power of a woman is her ability to create life.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A traditional view on the unique power associated with motherhood.

raw.text: The power of a man is his ability to protect his family.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A traditional view on the masculine role of protector.

raw.text: The power of a child is its innocence.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the disarming and morally potent nature of innocence.

raw.text: The power of an old man is his wisdom.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the value and authority that comes with age and experience.

raw.text: The power of a dog is its loyalty.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the simple, powerful nature of unconditional loyalty.

raw.text: The power of a cat is its independence.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the power that comes from self-sufficiency.

raw.text: The power of a book is its ability to transport you to another world.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the immersive and imaginative power of reading.

raw.text: The power of a tree is its ability to stand tall in a storm.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for resilience and strength in the face of adversity.

raw.text: The power of a river is its ability to carve a canyon.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the power of persistence and steady effort over time.

raw.text: The power of a mountain is its ability to make you feel small.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the humbling and perspective-giving power of nature.

raw.text: The power of the sea is its ability to calm the soul.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the therapeutic and calming influence of the ocean.

raw.text: The power of the sky is its ability to inspire wonder.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the awe-inspiring nature of the cosmos.

raw.text: The power of the sun is its ability to give life.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the fundamental, life-giving power of the sun.

raw.text: The power of the moon is its ability to move the tides.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for subtle but immense and predictable influence.

raw.text: The power of the stars is their ability to guide us.
raw.author: Proverb

raw.text: He who is brave is free.

raw.text: The brave man is he who overcomes not only his enemies but his pleasures.

raw.text: The whole future lies in uncertainty: live immediately.

raw.text: To be evenminded is the greatest virtue.

raw.text: The man who has anticipated the coming of troubles takes away their power when they arrive.

raw.text: The first rule is to keep an untroubled spirit. The second is to look things in the face and know them for what they are.

raw.text: No man is free who is not master of himself.

raw.text: It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it.

raw.text: If you wish to be an orator, you must be a good man.
