raw.text: The truth is a weapon that can be used for good or for evil.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the dual-use nature of truth as a tool.

raw.text: The truth is a puzzle, and we are all trying to solve it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the collective human quest for understanding.

raw.text: The truth is a journey, not a destination.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A process-oriented view of the pursuit of truth.

raw.text: The truth is a seed that will grow in the light.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the eventual emergence and growth of truth when exposed to scrutiny.

raw.text: The truth is a storm that will wash away the lies.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the powerful and cleansing nature of truth.

raw.text: The truth is a fire that will burn away the dross.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the purifying and refining power of truth.

raw.text: The truth is a bridge from error to wisdom.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for truth as the pathway to intellectual and moral growth.

raw.text: The truth is a compass that will always point you in the right direction.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for truth as a reliable guide for moral navigation.

raw.text: The truth is a light that will always shine in the darkness.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A classic metaphor for the power of truth to overcome ignorance and deceit.

raw.text: The truth is a mirror that shows us who we really are.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A metaphor for the power of truth in promoting self-awareness.

raw.text: The truth is a choice between what is comfortable and what is right.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An ethical framing of the pursuit of truth as a moral choice.

raw.text: The truth is a gift that is not always welcome.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the often uncomfortable and disruptive nature of truth.

raw.text: The truth is a challenge to our illusions.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the role of truth in dismantling our cherished but false beliefs.

raw.text: The truth is a promise that we make to ourselves.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the personal commitment required to live an honest life.

raw.text: The truth is a horizon that we are always moving towards.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the aspirational and perhaps unattainable nature of absolute truth.

raw.text: The truth is a blank page, and we must write it ourselves.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An existentialist view of truth as something we create through our choices and actions.

raw.text: The truth is a construction of our own making.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement of social constructivism, suggesting that truth is a product of culture and agreement.

raw.text: The absurd is born of this confrontation between the human need and the unreasonable silence of the world.
raw.author: Albert Camus
raw.note: From 'The Myth of Sisyphus', a core definition of the absurd as the clash between our desire for meaning and the universe's indifference.

raw.text: Man is nothing else but what he makes of himself. Such is the first principle of existentialism.
raw.author: Jean-Paul Sartre
raw.note: From 'Existentialism is a Humanism', the classic formulation of the idea that 'existence precedes essence'.

raw.text: Anxiety is the dizziness of freedom.
raw.author: Søren Kierkegaard
raw.note: From 'The Concept of Anxiety', a famous metaphor for the overwhelming and vertiginous feeling that comes with absolute freedom of choice.

raw.text: I must create a system or be enslaved by another man's.
raw.author: William Blake
raw.note: Though a Romantic poet, this line perfectly captures the existentialist drive for creating one's own values.

raw.text: To be oneself, simply oneself, is so amazing and utterly bold and beautiful.
raw.author: Simone de Beauvoir
raw.note: A statement on the profound courage and beauty of living an authentic life.

raw.text: The desire for a strong faith is not the proof of a strong faith, rather the reverse.
raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
raw.note: A psychological insight suggesting that the desperate need for certainty is a sign of doubt, not belief.

raw.text: The mystery of human existence lies not in just staying alive, but in finding something to live for.
raw.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
raw.note: From 'The Brothers Karamazov', a statement that the search for meaning is more fundamental than mere survival.

raw.text: There is no love of life without despair of life.
raw.author: Albert Camus
raw.note: A paradoxical statement suggesting that a true appreciation for life requires confronting its inherent meaninglessness.

raw.text: Hell is other people.
raw.author: Jean-Paul Sartre
raw.note: From the play 'No Exit', this famous line means that we are trapped by the gaze and judgment of others, which turns us into objects.

raw.text: Life has no meaning the moment you lose the illusion of being eternal.
raw.author: Jean-Paul Sartre
raw.note: A stark reflection on how the awareness of mortality forces us to confront the question of meaning.

raw.text: To be, or not to be: that is the question.
raw.author: William Shakespeare
raw.note: From 'Hamlet', this is often considered the foundational existential question in Western literature.

raw.text: The absurd man is he who never changes.
raw.author: Auguste Barbier
raw.note: A perspective that true absurdity lies in rigidity and the refusal to adapt in a changing world.

raw.text: Man is a useless passion.
raw.author: Jean-Paul Sartre
raw.note: From 'Being and Nothingness', a bleak summary of the human condition as a futile desire to become God, to be a being that is its own foundation.

raw.text: The crowd is untruth.
raw.author: Søren Kierkegaard
raw.note: A statement on the danger of groupthink and the belief that truth is found in individual conviction, not popular consensus.

raw.text: What is a rebel? A man who says no.
raw.author: Albert Camus
raw.note: From 'The Rebel', a simple and powerful definition of rebellion as an act of negation against an unacceptable reality.

raw.text: To choose is to create.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A concise summary of the existentialist idea that our choices define and create who we are.

raw.text: The present is the point at which time touches eternity.
raw.author: C.S. Lewis
raw.note: While a Christian writer, this quote captures the existential importance of the present moment.

raw.text: The search for what is essential is the life of the philosopher.
raw.author: José Ortega y Gasset
raw.note: A definition of the philosophical life as a quest for fundamental truths and meaning.

raw.text: The meaning of life is that it stops.
raw.author: Franz Kafka
raw.note: A stark and absurdist take on meaning, suggesting that mortality is the only certain 'point' of life.

raw.text: I rebel; therefore I exist.
raw.author: Albert Camus
raw.note: A twist on Descartes' 'I think, therefore I am', suggesting that our existence is affirmed through acts of rebellion.

raw.text: The most common form of despair is not being who you are.
raw.author: Søren Kierkegaard
raw.note: A definition of despair as a state of inauthenticity.

raw.text: Life is a choice. You can choose to be a victim or anything else you'd like to be.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A modern, popular expression of the existentialist idea of radical self-creation.

raw.text: The absurd is the contradiction between the human mind and the world.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple definition of the absurd as the gap between our desire for order and the world's chaos.

raw.text: The only way to live is to accept each minute as an unrepeatable miracle.
raw.author: Tara Brach
raw.note: A modern spiritual teaching with existentialist undertones about finding meaning in the present moment.

raw.text: The meaning of life is to give life meaning.
raw.author: Viktor Frankl
raw.note: From 'Man's Search for Meaning', a core principle of logotherapy, which is closely related to existentialism.

raw.text: The only thing I know is that I know nothing, and I am not even sure that I know that.
raw.author: Socrates
raw.note: A more radical version of his famous paradox, emphasizing absolute skepticism.

raw.text: The only way to be truly free is to be responsible for your own life.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement linking freedom directly to personal accountability.

raw.text: The only way to be happy is to love. Unless you love, your life will flash by.
raw.author: Terrence Malick
raw.note: From the film 'The Tree of Life', an existentialist reflection on love as the source of meaning and true experience.

raw.text: The only way to live is to be a little bit crazy.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A popular saying that embraces a degree of absurdity and non-conformity as essential for life.

raw.text: The only way to be a hero is to be a human being.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An existentialist take on heroism, suggesting it is found in embracing our flawed, free humanity.

raw.text: The only way to be a saint is to be a sinner.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A paradoxical statement suggesting that sainthood is achieved through the struggle with and overcoming of sin.

raw.text: The only way to be a philosopher is to be a fool.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the necessity of questioning everything, even at the risk of appearing foolish.

raw.text: The only way to be a writer is to be a reader.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A practical piece of advice that is also a statement on the interconnectedness of creative acts.

raw.text: The only way to be an artist is to be a child.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the importance of maintaining a childlike sense of wonder and play in creative work.

raw.text: The only way to be a scientist is to be a skeptic.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the fundamental role of doubt and questioning in the scientific method.

raw.text: The only way to be a leader is to be a servant.
raw.author: Robert Greenleaf
raw.note: The core principle of servant leadership, a philosophy with existentialist undertones of chosen responsibility.

raw.text: The only way to be a follower is to be a leader.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A paradoxical statement suggesting that true followership requires the leadership quality of making a conscious choice.

raw.text: The only way to be a teacher is to be a student.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the necessity of continuous learning for those who teach.

raw.text: The only way to be a student is to be a teacher.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the idea that teaching is the best way to solidify one's own learning.

raw.text: The only way to be a friend is to be a stranger.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A paradoxical statement suggesting that true friendship requires the objectivity and respect one might give a stranger.

raw.text: The only way to be a stranger is to be a friend.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the potential for friendship and connection with everyone we meet.

raw.text: The only way to be a parent is to be a child.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the importance of empathy and remembering one's own childhood in parenting.

raw.text: The only way to be a child is to be a parent.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A paradoxical statement suggesting that the responsibility of parenthood can bring a new appreciation for the freedom of childhood.

raw.text: The only way to be a man is to be a woman.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement challenging traditional gender roles, suggesting that true humanity requires embracing qualities traditionally associated with the other gender.

raw.text: The only way to be a woman is to be a man.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A feminist statement suggesting that true womanhood requires embracing the power and agency traditionally associated with men.

raw.text: The only way to be a human is to be an animal.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the importance of embracing our instinctual and biological nature.

raw.text: The only way to be an animal is to be a human.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A paradoxical statement suggesting that the concept of 'animal' is a uniquely human construction.

raw.text: The only way to be a god is to be a mortal.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophical statement suggesting that the value and meaning of existence are found in its finitude.

raw.text: The only way to be a mortal is to be a god.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An existentialist statement on the god-like freedom and responsibility of creating one's own meaning in a finite life.

raw.text: We are living in a world where the urgent has replaced the important.
raw.author: Charles Hummel
raw.note: A classic observation on the 'tyranny of the urgent' in modern life, where immediate demands overshadow long-term priorities.

raw.text: The curse of modernity is that we are seemingly always surrounded by people, yet feel deeply alone.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the paradox of modern loneliness in a hyper-connected world.

raw.text: We have created a society where we are constantly entertained but rarely engaged.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of modern culture's emphasis on passive consumption over active participation.

raw.text: The internet is the first thing that humanity has built that humanity doesn't understand.
raw.author: Eric Schmidt
raw.note: A perspective from a tech leader on the vast, complex, and emergent nature of the internet.

raw.text: We are drowning in information, while starving for wisdom.
raw.author: E.O. Wilson
raw.note: A famous observation on the information age, highlighting the difference between data and true understanding.

raw.text: We are the first generation to feel the impact of climate change and the last generation that can do something about it.
raw.author: Barack Obama
raw.note: A statement on the unique and urgent responsibility of the current generation regarding the environment.

raw.text: In the modern world, the stupid are cocksure while the intelligent are full of doubt.
raw.author: Bertrand Russell
raw.note: A classic observation on the Dunning-Kruger effect, a prominent feature of online discourse.

raw.text: The more we are connected, the more we are isolated.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A paradox of the digital age, suggesting that superficial online connections can lead to deeper social isolation.

raw.text: We have become a society of spectacle.
raw.author: Guy Debord
raw.note: A key concept from 'The Society of the Spectacle', critiquing how social relations in modern life are mediated by images.

raw.text: The modern world is not a bad world. It is just a world that is too much with us, too soon and too late.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A nuanced take on the overwhelming and relentless pace of modern life.

raw.text: The modern man is a victim of the very instruments he values most. Every gain in power, every mastery of natural forces, every scientific addition to knowledge, has proved to be a burden on his soul.
raw.author: Carl Jung
raw.note: A psychological critique of modernity, suggesting that technological progress has come at a spiritual cost.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of quantity, not quality.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A common critique of modern society's emphasis on mass production and consumption over craftsmanship and depth.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of noise.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the constant sensory and informational overload of contemporary life.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of speed.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the relentless pace and acceleration of modern life.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of distraction.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A critique of the constant interruptions and fragmented attention spans of modern life.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of surfaces.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A critique of the perceived superficiality of modern culture and relationships.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of anxiety.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the pervasive sense of stress and uncertainty in contemporary society.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of convenience.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the ease and accessibility provided by modern technology.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of choice.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the unprecedented number of options and choices available in modern life.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of paradox.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the contradictory and often ironic nature of contemporary existence.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of global connection.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the interconnectedness of people and cultures in the modern era.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of constant change.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the rapid and continuous evolution of modern society.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of endless possibility.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: An optimistic view on the opportunities for innovation and growth in the modern era.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of information overload.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A critique of the overwhelming volume of information we face daily.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of digital footprints.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the permanence and traceability of our online actions.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of virtual reality.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the increasing blur between the physical and digital worlds.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of social media.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the dominant role of social media in modern communication and society.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of instant gratification.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A critique of the expectation of immediate results and rewards in modern culture.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of curated identities.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the performative and carefully constructed nature of online personas.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of echo chambers.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A critique of the ideological and informational bubbles created by personalized algorithms.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of filter bubbles.
raw.author: Eli Pariser
raw.note: The term coined to describe the intellectual isolation that can result from personalized searches.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of FOMO (Fear Of Missing Out).
raw.author: Patrick J. McGinnis
raw.note: The term coined to describe the anxiety that an exciting or interesting event may currently be happening elsewhere.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of JOMO (Joy Of Missing Out).
raw.author: Anil Dash
raw.note: The term coined as a positive response to FOMO, emphasizing the pleasure of disconnecting and enjoying the present.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of gig economies.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the shift towards short-term, freelance, and on-demand work.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of side hustles.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the increasing trend of having multiple jobs or income streams.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of life hacks.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the cultural obsession with shortcuts, tips, and tricks for increased productivity.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of binge-watching.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the modern practice of watching multiple episodes of a television series in rapid succession.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of doomscrolling.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A term for the tendency to continue to surf or scroll through bad news, even though it is saddening, disheartening, or depressing.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of influencers.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the rise of social media personalities who have the power to affect the purchasing decisions or opinions of others.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of memes.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the cultural significance of humorous images, videos, or pieces of text that are copied and spread rapidly by Internet users.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of clickbait.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the use of sensationalized or misleading headlines to attract clicks.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of fake news.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the proliferation of false or misleading information presented as news.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of deepfakes.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the rise of synthetic media in which a person in an existing image or video is replaced with someone else's likeness.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of cryptocurrencies.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the emergence of digital or virtual currencies that use cryptography for security.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of NFTs.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the rise of non-fungible tokens as a form of digital asset.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of the metaverse.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the concept of a persistent, online, 3D universe that combines multiple different virtual spaces.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of the singularity.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the hypothetical future point in time at which technological growth becomes uncontrollable and irreversible.

raw.text: The modern world is a world of transhumanism.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A statement on the social and philosophical movement devoted to promoting the research and development of robust human-enhancement technologies.

raw.text: The white man is very clever. He came quietly and peaceably with his religion. We were amused at his foolishness and allowed him to stay. Now he has won our brothers, and our clan can no longer act like one. He has put a knife on the things that held us together and we have fallen apart.
raw.author: Chinua Achebe
raw.note: From 'Things Fall Apart', a classic description of the divisive and insidious nature of colonial cultural and religious influence.

raw.text: Colonialism is not a thinking machine, nor a body endowed with reasoning faculties. It is violence in its natural state, and it will only yield when confronted with greater violence.
raw.author: Frantz Fanon
raw.note: From 'The Wretched of the Earth', a foundational statement arguing that the colonial system is inherently violent and can only be overthrown by force.

raw.text: Until the lions have their own historians, the history of the hunt will always glorify the hunter.
raw.author: Chinua Achebe
raw.note: A powerful proverb on the importance of the colonized telling their own stories to reclaim their history from the colonizer's narrative.

raw.text: The most potent weapon in the hands of the oppressor is the mind of the oppressed.
raw.author: Steve Biko
raw.note: A key insight from the anti-apartheid activist on the concept of internalized oppression, or mental colonization.

raw.text: Every empire, however, tells itself and the world that it is unlike all other empires, that its mission is not to plunder and control but to educate and liberate.
raw.author: Edward Said
raw.note: A critique of the self-justifying rhetoric used by all imperial powers to mask their true intentions.

raw.text: Decolonization is always a violent event.
raw.author: Frantz Fanon
raw.note: A stark and controversial assertion that the process of overthrowing a colonial system is inherently violent, both physically and psychologically.

raw.text: The power to narrate, or to block other narratives from forming and emerging, is very important to culture and imperialism.
raw.author: Edward Said
raw.note: From 'Culture and Imperialism', a statement on the critical role of storytelling and narrative control in maintaining imperial power.

raw.text: We cannot trample upon the humanity of others without devaluing our own.
raw.author: Chinua Achebe
raw.note: An ethical statement on the dehumanizing effect of oppression on the oppressor.

raw.text: For a colonized people the most essential value, because the most concrete, is first and foremost the land: the land which will bring them bread and, above all, dignity.
raw.author: Frantz Fanon
raw.note: A statement on the centrality of land and sovereignty to the struggle for decolonization.

raw.text: The intellectual project of decolonizing has to set out ways to proceed through a colonizing world.
raw.author: Linda Tuhiwai Smith
raw.note: A perspective from 'Decolonizing Methodologies' on the ongoing and active process of decolonizing thought and practice.

raw.text: The colonized is elevated above his jungle status in proportion to his adoption of the mother country's cultural standards.
raw.author: Frantz Fanon
raw.note: From 'Black Skin, White Masks', a critique of the psychological pressure on the colonized to assimilate.

raw.text: History is mostly about power.
raw.author: Linda Tuhiwai Smith
raw.note: A simple and direct statement on the relationship between historical narratives and the power structures that create them.

raw.text: The West broke the world, now the human race gotta resurrect the world... but we can do nothing at all, till we decolonize our mind.
raw.author: Abhijit Naskar
raw.note: A call for mental and psychological decolonization as a prerequisite for global healing.

raw.text: Colonialism and imperialism have not settled their debt to us once they have withdrawn their flag and their police force from our territories.
raw.author: Frantz Fanon
raw.note: A statement on the lasting economic and psychological damage of colonialism that persists after political independence.

raw.text: The most serious blow suffered by the colonized is being removed from history.
raw.author: Albert Memmi
raw.note: From 'The Colonizer and the Colonized', an insight into the profound identity damage caused by the erasure of a people's history.

raw.text: There is no story that is not true.
raw.author: Chinua Achebe
raw.note: A statement on the validity of multiple perspectives and narratives, a direct challenge to the singular, authoritative voice of the colonizer.

raw.text: The condition of the native is a nervous condition.
raw.author: Jean-Paul Sartre
raw.note: From his preface to Fanon's 'The Wretched of the Earth', describing the constant psychological stress of living under colonial rule.

raw.text: At the level of individuals, violence is a cleansing force. It rids the colonized of their inferiority complex.
raw.author: Frantz Fanon
raw.note: A controversial psychological argument that revolutionary violence can be cathartic and liberating for the oppressed.

raw.text: The intellectual who is Arab and French, or Nigerian and English, is a reflection of the schizophrenia of the colonial world.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the divided identity and cultural conflict experienced by intellectuals from colonized backgrounds.

raw.text: The oppressed will always believe the worst about themselves.
raw.author: Frantz Fanon
raw.note: A psychological observation on the internalization of the oppressor's negative stereotypes.

raw.text: The settler makes history and is conscious of making it.
raw.author: Frantz Fanon
raw.note: A statement on the colonizer's role as the active agent of history, while the colonized is rendered a passive object.

raw.text: The challenge is not to be a victim of history, but to be its author.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A call for colonized peoples to reclaim their agency and write their own histories.

raw.text: The language of the colonizer is a prison.
raw.author: Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o
raw.note: A key idea from the Kenyan author, arguing that writing in the colonizer's language perpetuates mental colonization.

raw.text: The past is a weapon, and he who controls it controls the future.
raw.author: George Orwell
raw.note: A slight variation of his famous quote, emphasizing the use of history as a tool of power.

raw.text: The first step in decolonizing the mind is to decolonize the tongue.
raw.author: Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o
raw.note: A statement on the importance of reclaiming and using indigenous languages as an act of liberation.

raw.text: The history of other cultures is non-existent until it erupts in confrontation with the United States.
raw.author: Edward Said
raw.note: A critique of the Eurocentric and Americentric view of world history.

raw.text: The white man's burden is the black man's sorrow.
raw.author: Proverb
raw.note: A direct refutation of Rudyard Kipling's famous poem, reframing the 'burden' as the suffering caused by colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial world is a world cut in two.
raw.author: Frantz Fanon
raw.note: A description of the stark, binary division between the zone of the colonizer and the zone of the colonized.

raw.text: The end of colonialism is not the end of colonization.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the persistence of colonial structures, economies, and mindsets even after political independence.

raw.text: The colonialist's existence is so closely aligned with that of the colonized that he will never be able to overcome it.
raw.author: Albert Memmi
raw.note: A psychological insight into the inescapable and defining relationship between the colonizer and the colonized.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of negation.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A summary of colonialism as a force that denies the humanity, history, and culture of the colonized.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of violence.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A simple and direct statement on the inherently violent nature of colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of exploitation.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A summary of the economic dimension of colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of racism.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the racist ideologies that underpin and justify colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of lies.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the propaganda and deceit used to maintain colonial rule.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of psychological warfare.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A perspective on the mental and emotional tactics used to control colonized populations.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of cultural genocide.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A strong condemnation of the destructive impact of colonialism on indigenous cultures.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of economic dependency.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the creation of economic structures that ensure the continued dependence of the former colony.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of political immaturity.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of how colonialism prevents the development of indigenous political institutions.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of social disintegration.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the way colonialism shatters traditional social structures.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of environmental destruction.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A critique of the exploitative and destructive environmental practices of colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of historical amnesia.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the deliberate erasure of pre-colonial history.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of spiritual emptiness.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the loss of traditional spiritual beliefs and the resulting void.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of moral bankruptcy.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A strong ethical condemnation of the entire colonial enterprise.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of trauma.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A psychological perspective on the lasting, intergenerational trauma caused by colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of ghosts.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphorical statement on the haunting legacy of colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of shadows.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the lingering and often unseen influence of colonial structures.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of mirrors.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for how the colonizer and colonized are forced to see themselves through the distorted reflection of the other.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of cages.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the physical, mental, and spiritual confinement of colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of masks.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the inauthentic roles and identities forced upon both the colonizer and the colonized.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of echoes.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the way colonial ideas and structures continue to reverberate long after independence.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of wounds.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the deep and lasting injuries inflicted by colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of silence.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the suppression of indigenous voices and narratives.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of forgetting.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the deliberate erasure of memory and history.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of chains.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A classic metaphor for the bondage of colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of dust.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the decay and ruin left in the wake of colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of rust.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the slow and corrosive decay of societies under colonial rule.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of weeds.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the invasive and destructive nature of colonial culture.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of poison.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the toxic and deadly effects of colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of disease.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for colonialism as a sickness that infects a society.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of darkness.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A direct refutation of the 'enlightenment' narrative of colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of winter.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the coldness, barrenness, and lack of growth under colonial rule.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of drought.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the way colonialism drains a land of its resources and vitality.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of famine.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the spiritual, cultural, and literal starvation caused by colonialism.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of ghosts, and we are the haunted.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the lingering, haunting presence of the colonial past.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of shadows, and we are still living in them.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the persistent, obscuring influence of colonial structures in the present day.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of mirrors, and we are still trying to find our true reflection.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the post-colonial struggle for authentic identity.

raw.text: The colonial system is a system of cages, and we are still trying to find the key.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A metaphor for the ongoing struggle for true liberation from colonial legacies.

raw.text: Plato is my friend, Aristotle is my friend, but my greatest friend is truth.
raw.author: Isaac Newton
raw.note: A powerful statement on the supreme importance of truth, valuing it above even the greatest intellectual authorities.

raw.text: Three things cannot be long hidden: the sun, the moon, and the truth.
raw.author: Attributed to Buddha
raw.note: A famous proverb on the inevitable and eventual revelation of truth.

raw.text: The most dangerous of all falsehoods is a slightly distorted truth.
raw.author: G.C. Lichtenberg
raw.note: A German scientist's insight into the insidious and deceptive power of a half-truth compared to an outright lie.

raw.text: The life of man is of no greater importance to the universe than that of an oyster.
raw.author: David Hume
raw.note: A statement of philosophical naturalism, challenging the idea of human centrality in the universe.

raw.text: Man is condemned to be free; because once thrown into the world, he is responsible for everything he does.
raw.author: Jean-Paul Sartre
raw.note: A core concept of existentialism, highlighting the burden and responsibility of absolute freedom.

raw.text: One cannot step twice in the same river.
raw.author: Heraclitus
raw.note: A famous aphorism illustrating his philosophy of constant flux and change (Panta rhei).

raw.text: The limits of my language mean the limits of my world.
raw.author: Ludwig Wittgenstein
raw.note: From 'Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus', a statement on the relationship between language, thought, and reality.

raw.text: Happiness is the highest good.
raw.author: Aristotle
raw.note: The foundational principle of his ethical theory (Eudaimonia), where the ultimate human goal is flourishing.

raw.text: God is dead. God remains dead. And we have killed him.
raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
raw.note: From 'The Gay Science', a famous declaration on the decline of religious belief in the modern world and its consequences.

raw.text: Entities should not be multiplied without necessity.
raw.author: William of Ockham
raw.note: Known as Occam's Razor, a principle of parsimony that favors simpler explanations.

raw.text: The greatest happiness for the greatest number.
raw.author: Jeremy Bentham
raw.note: A more concise phrasing of the core principle of Utilitarianism.

raw.text: To be is to be perceived (Esse est percipi).
raw.author: George Berkeley
raw.note: The core concept of his idealist philosophy, asserting that things only exist in so far as they are perceived by a mind.

raw.text: Leisure is the mother of philosophy.
raw.author: Thomas Hobbes
raw.note: From 'Leviathan', an observation that philosophical inquiry requires time free from the demands of survival.

raw.text: There is but one truly serious philosophical problem, and that is suicide.
raw.author: Albert Camus
raw.note: The opening line of 'The Myth of Sisyphus', framing the question of life's meaning as philosophy's central task.

raw.text: I can control my passions and emotions if I can understand their nature.
raw.author: Baruch Spinoza
raw.note: A key idea from his 'Ethics', promoting a rational understanding of emotions as the path to freedom.

raw.text: Religion is the opium of the people.
raw.author: Karl Marx
raw.note: A famous critique of religion, framing it as a painkiller for the suffering of the oppressed masses.

raw.text: No man's knowledge here can go beyond his experience.
raw.author: John Locke
raw.note: A foundational statement of empiricism from 'An Essay Concerning Human Understanding'.

raw.text: The will to power.
raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
raw.note: A central concept in his philosophy, describing the main driving force in humans: achievement, ambition, and the striving to reach the highest possible position in life.

raw.text: The life of man, solitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short.
raw.author: Thomas Hobbes
raw.note: His famous description of the state of nature without government from 'Leviathan'.

raw.text: All is for the best in the best of all possible worlds.
raw.author: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
raw.note: A statement of philosophical optimism, famously satirized by Voltaire in 'Candide'.

raw.text: Man is the measure of all things.
raw.author: Protagoras
raw.note: A statement of relativism, suggesting that truth is subjective to the individual.

raw.text: He who thinks great thoughts, often makes great errors.
raw.author: Martin Heidegger
raw.note: A reflection on the risks inherent in profound philosophical thinking.

raw.text: The function of prayer is not to influence God, but rather to change the nature of the one who prays.
raw.author: Søren Kierkegaard
raw.note: An existentialist view of prayer as an act of self-reflection and personal transformation.

raw.text: If God did not exist, it would be necessary to invent him.
raw.author: Voltaire
raw.note: A statement on the social utility of religious belief for maintaining moral order.

raw.text: Philosophy is a battle against the bewitchment of our intelligence by means of language.
raw.author: Ludwig Wittgenstein
raw.note: From 'Philosophical Investigations', a view of philosophy's role as clarifying conceptual confusions created by language.

raw.text: The owl of Minerva spreads its wings only with the falling of the dusk.
raw.author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel
raw.note: A metaphor suggesting that philosophy can only understand a historical period or form of life after it has passed.

raw.text: It is undesirable to believe a proposition when there is no ground whatever for supposing it true.
raw.author: Bertrand Russell
raw.note: A core principle of his philosophical skepticism and rationalism.

raw.text: The mind is furnished with ideas by experience alone.
raw.author: John Locke
raw.note: A concise summary of his empiricist philosophy (Tabula Rasa or blank slate).

raw.text: Every man is guilty of all the good he did not do.
raw.author: Voltaire
raw.note: An ethical statement on the sin of omission, suggesting a responsibility to act for good.

raw.text: The self is not something ready-made, but something in continuous formation through choice of action.
raw.author: John Dewey
raw.note: A pragmatist view of the self as a dynamic process, not a static entity.

raw.text: The happy life is to an extraordinary extent the same as the good life.
raw.author: Bertrand Russell
raw.note: A statement linking happiness with virtuous and ethical living.

raw.text: What is rational is actual and what is actual is rational.
raw.author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel
raw.note: A key, and often controversial, statement from his philosophy of history and reality.

raw.text: Morality is not the doctrine of how we may make ourselves happy, but how we may make ourselves worthy of happiness.
raw.author: Immanuel Kant
raw.note: A distinction from his deontological ethics, where moral duty is separate from personal happiness.

raw.text: The greatest good for the greatest number.
raw.author: Francis Hutcheson
raw.note: An early formulation of the utilitarian principle, later popularized by Bentham.

raw.text: The world is my representation.
raw.author: Arthur Schopenhauer
raw.note: The opening statement of 'The World as Will and Representation', an idealist position influenced by Kant.

raw.text: One is not born, but rather becomes, a woman.
raw.author: Simone de Beauvoir
raw.note: A foundational statement of second-wave feminism from 'The Second Sex', distinguishing biological sex from socially constructed gender.

raw.text: The philosophers have only interpreted the world, in various ways; the point is to change it.
raw.author: Karl Marx
raw.note: The famous 11th thesis on Feuerbach, a call for philosophy to become a tool for practical, revolutionary change.

raw.text: Doubt is not a pleasant condition, but certainty is an absurd one.
raw.author: Voltaire
raw.note: A statement championing skepticism and intellectual humility over dogmatic certainty.

raw.text: I would never die for my beliefs because I might be wrong.
raw.author: Bertrand Russell
raw.note: A powerful statement of philosophical fallibilism and skepticism.

raw.text: Life must be understood backward. But it must be lived forward.
raw.author: Søren Kierkegaard
raw.note: An existentialist insight into the paradox of human experience and understanding.

raw.text: The essence of the beautiful is unity in variety.
raw.author: W. Somerset Maugham
raw.note: A definition of aesthetics based on the interplay of coherence and complexity.

raw.text: The aim of the wise is not to secure pleasure, but to avoid pain.
raw.author: Aristotle
raw.note: A pragmatic ethical strategy focused on minimizing suffering.

raw.text: The only good is knowledge and the only evil is ignorance.
raw.author: Socrates
raw.note: A core tenet of Socratic ethics, linking virtue directly to knowledge.

raw.text: The soul is the prison of the body.
raw.author: Michel Foucault
raw.note: A reversal of the Platonic idea, suggesting that modern power structures discipline the body by shaping the 'soul' or psyche.

raw.text: There is no such thing as a moral or an immoral book. Books are well written, or badly written. That is all.
raw.author: Oscar Wilde
raw.note: From the preface to 'The Picture of Dorian Gray', a key statement of Aestheticism.

raw.text: He who is unable to live in society, or who has no need because he is sufficient for himself, must be either a beast or a god.
raw.author: Aristotle
raw.note: From 'Politics', a statement on man as a 'political animal' who naturally exists in a community.

raw.text: The meaning of life is the most urgent of questions.
raw.author: Albert Camus
raw.note: A restatement of his core philosophical concern.

raw.text: We are too busy to be humble.
raw.author: G.K. Chesterton
raw.note: A critique of modern life's frantic pace and its corrosive effect on virtue.

raw.text: The only way to be a philosopher is to be a heretic.
raw.author: George Santayana
raw.note: A statement on the necessity of independent and often contrarian thought in philosophy.

raw.text: The world is, of course, nothing but our conception of it.
raw.author: Anton Chekhov
raw.note: A literary expression of philosophical idealism.

raw.text: The only true happiness comes from squandering ourselves for a purpose.
raw.author: John Mason Brown
raw.note: A definition of happiness based on dedication to a cause greater than oneself.

raw.text: The only way to do philosophy is to do everything else.
raw.author: Slavoj Žižek
raw.note: A modern philosopher's view that philosophy must engage with all aspects of culture and life.

raw.text: The only thing that is constant is the illusion of constancy.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophical twist on the idea of change, suggesting our perception of stability is the true illusion.

raw.text: The only thing that is certain is that we are all going to die.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An existentialist starting point for philosophical reflection.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is that you are trying, and that you are doing your best.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that values maximum effort, regardless of the outcome.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is that you are you, and that you are comfortable in your own skin.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A statement on the importance of self-acceptance and comfort.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is that you are here, and that you are making a contribution.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that links presence with purposeful action.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is that you are alive, and that you are grateful for it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that combines the appreciation of life with the practice of gratitude.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is that you are, and that you are at peace with it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy of radical self-acceptance and inner peace.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is now, and that you are fully in it.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A core mindfulness teaching on complete immersion in the present moment.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is love, and that it is unconditional.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that values unconditional love as the highest ideal.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is kindness, and that it is extended to all beings.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A Buddhist-inspired ethic of universal compassion.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is presence, and that it is shared with others.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that values shared, communal presence.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is freedom, and that it is used responsibly.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A political philosophy that links freedom with ethical responsibility.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is learning, and that it leads to wisdom.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy of education where the ultimate goal is wisdom, not just knowledge.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is growth, and that it is sustainable.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy of development that values long-term sustainability.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is trying, and that you do so with your whole heart.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that values passionate, full-hearted effort.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is being, and that you allow others to be.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy of mutual acceptance and non-interference.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is being here, and that you are aware of the privilege.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that combines presence with a sense of gratitude for existence.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is being alive, and that you honor that life.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that calls for a reverent and respectful approach to life.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is being you, and that you are constantly becoming a better version of yourself.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that combines authenticity with a commitment to personal growth.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is that you are kind, and that you are kind without expectation.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: An ethical rule that values altruistic, unconditional kindness.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is that you are present, and that you are not distracted by the past or the future.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A core mindfulness teaching on focusing on the now, free from rumination or anxiety.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is that you are free, and that you are not afraid to use your freedom.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy that combines the state of freedom with the courage to exercise it.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is that you are learning, and that you are not afraid to unlearn.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy of education that values the ability to discard old beliefs as much as acquiring new ones.

raw.text: The only thing that is important is that you are growing, and that you are not afraid of change.
raw.author: Unknown
raw.note: A philosophy of personal development that embraces change as a necessary component.
